Ratings.comment: I love Dr. H! Her class was a lot of work, but everything was organized very clearly so you always know what's expected of you. She also gives way more personalized feedback than I've ever had from an online course, which I really appreciated.

VERY VERY VERY harsh grader. Would not recommend to anyone that isn’t a history buff/has prior knowledge. I’d say each week you have to read on average 15 pages of excerpts and 20 minutes of videos and then have to write a 250 word discussion post + 250 word reply to a classmate. The discussion questions are typically vague as well.

online class with ton of reading. Lectures just a video of her talking, no slides or visualization. discussion posts graded harshly and count for more than half of grade. Hard to keep up with if have other classes that are also difficult. Do not recommend if not looking into career in history if do not have good knowledge of events already.
Dr. Honchell is an amazing professor! Her class was easily one of my favorites! Oh and by the way, she's gorgeous!

Professor Honchell is an extraordinary gifted professor; a woman with tremendous promise-- diligent, quick, clever, and thoughtful. In terms of her maturity for work, including understanding the fact that teaching is the consequence of hours of careful, patient and diligent effort. I would rank her in the top 3 professors I've taken at OSU.

I found this boring. She assumes everyone has knowledge about the topics already so it's hard to catch up if you don't know a significant amount already. I wouldn't bother taking this class again. Much easier options than this one.
This was probably one of the best classes I've ever taken. Honestly, Stephanie kickstarted my interest in an entire field. She's a fantastic teacher and I loved the lectures and engagement.

Stephanie is really nice and explain the subject really well. She really makes the subject material come to life. She is very approachable and flexible. Sometimes I felt like she was more of a friend than a teacher. Class format is great too, all discussion almost no lecture. Never boring. The books are great as well.
This class was slightly difficult but interesting. Usually a diff professor though. She is a great teacher and very available for questions. Flexible as well with student needs.

Awesome professor. Makes history come alive and is clearly passionate about the subject. You won't regret taking this class. She used to teach at louisville so you can look up her old profile if you want more reviews

Hands down my favorite professor in three years at TOSU. She is kind and funny and adorable when she gets going on the connections between now and 100 years ago (this is a big thing with her, if you want to fill up time).

My favorite. She is passionate about everything she teaches and I look forward to her bubbly emails and videos. There is a lot of reading and the class is made up of daily quizzes and extra credit but the quizzes are easy if you even skim and hard if you don't. It is a short summer class and I would take it again even though it is a lot every day.

Grade was a C because I skipped discussion and the Extra Credit made it an A. The Extra Credit work was Extra interesting and she encouraged me to use the time to research things like my family history. Abuela cried when I asked her questions and thanks to DrH I am going to keep asking her questions in summer. Take any class you can from this gem.

I took Professor Hayder to graduate in May. I added the class late and for two weeks she met with me to catch up. I could not buy the book and she bought it for me. I had to go to court and she changed two deadlines for me. DrH was kind and funny and so excited about history that I got excited too.
All Around Great

I love DrH! Her vibe is so loving and caring, she cares so much about how you're doing and if you understand and are keeping up. I added a second major in history because I hav taken a lot of her classes. She assigns a lot to read and watch but nothing is hard. Would it be weird if I asked her to be my friend irl

Professor Hayder is the nicest professor Ive had while being at Ohio State. This class involves a lot of reading and watching documentaries and then you have a quiz over it each week. The quizzes are kinda hard but she does give you many opportunities for extra credit which is nice.
I love her! There is a lot of reading but everything is easy. She sent the class an email with "Drunk History" episodes included, love her. She is my favorite professor at OSU so far.

Initially I was not a fan. The quizzes are difficult if you dont watch the movies (which can be lengthy) and at least skim the readings. However, Haydar is more than willing to help you if you just ask for it! One of the most kindest profs Ive had and truly cares about each students learning and well being!! would highly recommend taking!

I have taken a class with Professor Haydar every semester for the past year as part of The Ohio State University's Program 60. Prof. Hyadar is conscientious, picks very interesting sources and has an infectious enthusiasm for her subjects. I wish to take her classes in person soon.
Helped me start class late nice with giving me more time

I am not a history major but needed this course for upper GE. Grade is based on 8 quizzes, lowest two being dropped. Sounds easy but the questions are HARD. All multiple choice that could be multiple answers type of thing. Frustrating to say the least because it sounds like it should be easier than it is. Also, SO much reading and 1-2 movies a week
Dr. Haydar is my only prof this semester who respects Fall Break. She is flexible and kind!
Professor Hadar is nicest I have at TOSU. She explains a lot and connects everything to what is happening now. in midTerms, she assigned podcasts and documentaries. Really nice.

I didn know I would like this class as much as I do. DrH split the reading for the summer so it's about half reading and half documentaries. The class is organized well, daily quiz after every assignment.

Easiest history class in 4 weeks. Readings all on Carmen, about 20 pages to read every day. If you Ctl-F for the hard quiz questions in the book, you find it. Went to office hours, she's nice. If you can't do well at this, dont take a 4 week class, dummy.

I took this class during the summer and it is AWFUL! Every day there are about 30 pages of reading and a quiz to test you on the reading. I am personally a really slow reader so it takes about 2-3 hours for me. Quizzes are not online so there is no way to search it up. If you are taking this class for GE and taking it during the summer, SKIP!

Last class with Dr. Haydar today and miss her already. Funny and makes Islamic and Middle East History easy to understand. She has a record player in her background on Zoom and I wrote down all the stuff she had on there. checked it out. All fire! Gonna take her again. don't care what the class is.

Dr. Haydar is seriously so kind and thoughtful and willing to help out whenever some of the course's more confusing topics can trip students up. I had no previous experience with any of the material presented in this class, but I don't feel like I missed out because of that even though I thought I would! Loved this class and loved Dr. Haydar!!

Srsly nicest prof i have had. class is online because covid and syllabus is half of what it looked like it was in person. mult choice weekly quiz can be sneaky because she makes some answers seem real except for one ridiculous word, so read them slowly. gave me lots of help with project, was really flex when I needed a break, very cool if you care.

Dr H is super kind, if you need help ask for it! The online Covid version was a lot of reading the first few weeks but then it lightened up to films. You get a weekly quiz and 4 sentence summary on the readings. There is also a term paper that's your final and you work on the entire class. Def recommend you take this if interested in the Mid East!

5th year senior, took this class for fun. She made it easy to understand the Middle East, but more important is the nicest professor I've ever had. I just read an email from her where she was making sure that we had food for Thanksgiving because of the Ohio restrictions. 'If you don't have plans, let's put one together for you.' 10/10, the best

I'm taking Dr. Haydar for modern middle east right now and this is my first year. I didn't pay attention in social studies in high school and It's not an introduction history class, so it takes a lot of work to get familiar. She is so nice and has met with me every week to help me with explaining things, even helping me with how to take notes.

There were no lectures in this Covid-version of the course, making the information hard to comprehend. Would assign tons of difficult reading material and have almost no powerpoints to follow. Meeting with the teacher herself isn't a pleasant experience, she tends to get hostile if you give criticism of the course structure. Would not recommend.

I'm currently taking this class online this semester and it's my biggest regret as far as education goes. The professor refuses to do the bare minimum to teach this course and instead assigns over 100 pages of reading per week from dated complex sources, and overall treats this class like it is worth 5 credit hours. No lectures. Don't recommend.

I don't know what this class is like in person, but the Covid version is a lot of work on your own. She said that there wouldnt be recorded lectures because people don't want them anyway, so the only way to get explanation from her is to attend the optional live class discussions. She's funny and responds right away but won't chase you down.

I really enjoyed Professor Chisebe's class. Her class is structured well and although work intensive the content is engaging. She is welcoming and is always willing to work with her students. READ HER SYLLABUS. you will understand that she gives you many drops and extra credit opportunities. You should enjoy reading and writing weekly to pass.

Dawn Chisebe thinks only of her class and nothing else. With that being said, she LOADS on the work so be prepared to read and write. Her critiquing gives you the illusion you cannot do anything to please her. She claims her informative announcements and videos help, but I personally think theyre a waste of time. I would not recommend her class!

She was okay. She was usually nice and responded to emails quickly, and you could definitely tell she really wanted you to learn/grow. But this class was just set up in a way that was so repetitive and it got super boring super quickly and it made me hate doing the work for this class.

Dawn was a great professor and treated us students like adults which I appreciate. She also kept things quite interesting in the homework assignments given to us. I liked completing discussion boards! Shes a great professor just definitely pay attention to the textbook and think critically!
I took the class online, it is a lot of reading out of the textbook but she is a very easy grader as long as you do the work.
I adore Dawn so much. She rlly makes sure that all her students feel included. Just be ready for a lot of talking, writing, and reading.

AU 19. Took the online class. Discussion posts and replies due every week, which you have to read at least one chapter for. Exams and papers aren't too bad. All I have to say is that they gave SO much extra credit (and I think it was curved at the end?), like I'm talking I wound up with over a 100% in the class. Not a bad class!

Professor Chiesbe is a hard grader for no reason. Every week, you have to do a discussion post on 80 pages of a book that is 300 words and two 150 word responses to a peer but its only worth FIVE POINTS! It makes u not wanna be in the class bc youre doing tons of reading for only FIVE points. Then, shell give you a 4.7 without any explanation

Dawn Miles is a smart woman and I would take her class again. She knows her history and actually makes you interested and aware of what's going on in Africa, as it pertains to the rest of world. If your class is online, just pay attention to due dates and you'll get an easy A. She offered more extra credit than assignments that were actually due.
Very interesting class, many opportunities for extra credit
If you show up to class, you'll get a good grade. This class was very interesting and she's one of my favorite teachers. I recommend my friends to take this class and they loved her as well

Dawn was nothing but amazing.  Dawn knows her stuff to a T.  She is the most knowledgable woman I have had as a professor here, along with being the biggest sweetheart.  Always helpful and eager to teach. She also brings in food and offers tons of EC opportunities :)
This was an online class. Everything was superb and overall I learned a lot from this class. Recommend this instructor!

Maybe because its online but this class sucked. Our grade was 3 papers and a few short responses. We also had 5 random quizzes that I have no clue where the questions came from because they were so random. Lecture heavy and his powerpoints are 100+ slides with random information on them, like you cant even really take notes. Wouldnt recommend.

Prof. Brooke is a very nice person, and he always gives immediate and very detailed response to your questions. His lectures are a little bit too long and boring, and you really need to study for extra time after class in order to fully learn the content. However, tests are not very detail-oriented. Weekly pre-lab readings heavy but fine.

Great professor, great guy. Respected in the department and for his research. Readings were helpful for papers and good supplements to the lectures. Lectures would have 100+ slides and were a little dry. If you work hard on the papers and actually respond to the prompts, you will get an A.
Rounded my 87 to an A but that's because I used him as a resource throughout the semester and asked him a lot of questions. Show you're interested and things will work in your favor.

Not a fan of the quizzes, as not many people knew what to expect. I studied all the slides and still did well, but there were still a few things that I wasn't expecting on the quiz. That might just be more of an issue of how the class is run than Brooke himself, but if I were you, don't take this class for the GE cred.
Very nice and brilliant professor, but he is disorganized. His lectures are all over the place and he likes to go off on tangents when asked a question.

Dr. Brooke is extremely knowledgable on early American history and an enthusiastic teacher. His lectures can jump around with lengthy PowerPoints, so you have to pay attention and attend class to do well. Readings are also interesting. Incorporate quotes from assigned readings and from lecture material, prove you understand it, and you'll get an A.

Attendance for lecture and recitation.  Tells you to buy 7 books at the start of the semester I opened 2 for 10 mins total to find 2 quotes.  3 parts to the class and 3 papers plus a final which is basically your grade plus participation and easy 20 minute 1 page papers for section.  Did other hw in lecture whole time & didnt read and wasnt behind

John Brooke is clearly very smart, yet his lack of organization skills - in both activities and lecture - make it difficult to learn anything in his class. Daily powerpoints with hundreds of slides and tons of books that you have to rent only to read snippets.

Dr. Brooke knows his stuff but has a hard time organizing his lecture into a logical pattern, so it can be really hard to follow. He goes very quickly, jumping between slides, so note taking can be challenging. Attendance is mandatory. He gives essay assignments as exams, which is nice bc multiple choice would be impossible due to disorganization

The lectures are confusing, and BORING. He is extremely knowledgeable but his lectures are hard to follow and impossible to take notes on. I had to buy 4 different books for the class that don't have that much to do with the material.

Dr. Brooke is PERFECT and the class is AMAZING. There's lots of reading, but it's all INTERESTING. He picks great books on great topics. He's also incredibly knowledgeable and has so many fascinating insights on the topics we study. If you don't want to work hard, don't take his class, but if you come in ready to learn, you'll have a great time!

As a history major, focusing in American Political History I was so excited to take this class. However as time went on Professor Brooke made me bored and disinterested in my own passions. He is disorganized to the brink of incompetency. Each day there is a new PowerPoint with at LEAST 140 slides, which is entirely unnecessary and overwhelming.

Lecture takes attendance. Scholarly lecture. Really hard to comprehend if you arent focused.Three essay quizzes are easy but you must read at least the online textbook he provides in order to get an A and use that info in your essays. quizzes are take home, in class with notes, and solo.
Brooke was very hard to understand in class. However, he was very helpful in office hours and always willing to look at your assignment and give you some tips before handing it in.

History of Global Enviro:All grading is done based on 3 5-page essays throughout the quarter. Attendance is taken during class and worth almost 20% of your grade. This stinks because he basically just lectures to himself the whole time and faces his slides (w/ a million charts and graphs that he flips through). Hes a nice guy but lecture is boring

Prof. John Brooke is an amazing asset to the history department at Ohio State.  He is widely accepted as one of the top scholars in his field and this extends beyond his own research into the classroom.  His enthusiasm is unparalleled and students should expect to learn alot.
Dr. Brooke is the man

This guy might as well stand up and read from the textbook, his lectures are so boring and uninspired. he is disorganized and tends to get way ahead of himself. His lecture style is unclear and he fails to focus on key themes and events. He consistently ran over class time despite the class being 3 days a week. Avoid.

I had no idea what his lectures were about. He doesnt stay on topic so i personally quit going to lectures. BUT THE RTAP. Its like ur bible for this class. The paper we had to write was dumb. I DISLIKED my TA Dave Hadley. Go to recitations. I never went to lecture tho.

lectures are EXTREMELY boring, but professor brooke is very knowledgeable about history and is passionate about his work. he's a good teacher if you can manage to pay attention. it is difficult to take notes on his lectures, so just listen and take notes in recitation instead.

Wonderful professor!  He is not disorganized and all over the place like other reviewers mentioned.  He will do anything to help you.  I went to his office for advice on the final paper and he was very helpful.  His exams are great AS LONG AS YOU STUDY THE REVIEW GUIDE!  He gives you everything you need to know.  The only bad part is the reading.

Plan on teaching yourself for most of the course. He's very disorganized and it's difficult to take notes. He has powerpoints but he goes out of order most of the time. And has a ton of slides. He wants you to know so much but it's unrealistic. Over 100+ pages of reading a night.

Very random, his lectures have no clear flow which makes notetaking hard, then again everything he says is in the book or RTAP so you could just read and not go to class,recitation's kind of a waste, easy class since RTAP's are allowed in exams, nice guy, he'll answer any question you have, between him and another prof, i'd say take him

I agree that his lectures are scattered, but the class still isn't hard. Buy the RTAP, you get to use it on the tests (with notes in it for your essays if you realize it). But he is full of knowledge and can be amazing to listen to at times.

If you think that anything worth reading about in American History must have been done by old, white New Englanders then this is the class for you. There must have been no women, southerners, blacks or natives in early america because you sure won't hear about them from him. Easy class, he is a smart guy, but there are much better professors.

lectures are very scattered.  he talks to students about the subject matter as if we're already experts in the field.  aside from this, if you email him or visit him during office hours he's willing to help as much as he can.

This was one of the worst intructors I have EVER had at OSU!! His teaching is all over the place and about nothing half the time. He seems to be a very intelligent man but he treats his students like his colleges that should know all the useless info that he knows... I HATE THIS CLASS!!!

He does not control your grade on the essays, your TA does, his lecturing is a bit fast, but he loves what he teaches and is enthusiastic, fun to listen to, he's helpful too, really though, you could either attend lecture or read foner, you don't need both, buy RTAP, you get to use open book on tests, just take him, it's bearable and an easy GEC

Almost spit water all over my screen when i readt the "huge" quote at the top of the page. Was wondering if anyone else noticed that he did this. Anyhow this guy is pretty hard to follow, he does not give very good notes. He tends to scatter things out quite a bit and jumps around from topic to topic a lot. But this course wasn't too difficult.
Not bad.  Midterm 1 was extremely easy because it was open book and they told you before the test what you needed to write about.
Way too much reading. Three textbooks to buy. lectures ae hard to follow.

Took the class for a GEC and had no idea what I was getting myself into. I ended up dropping and taking a W because I was totally lost, even though I'd done the absurd amounts of reading and attended his scattered lectures.  Went for help and he said that he didn't recommend the class for non-majors and  didn't give any more help or guidance.

Lecture's is too scattered and he tries to cover way to much info all at once.  It's like an upper level Environ. cience and Anthro class combined, and Anthro department does a much better job at being coherent.  Too much reading for one class, also, don't fall for his take-home exams.
Lecture was totally boring and it was unnecessary because I had a great TA( Rachel Ball) who went over everything that we needed to know in recitation. Pulled an A-.

lectures are totally useless, recitation is totally useless. All powerpoint notes are online and i maybe went to 5 lectures, and a little over half of the recitations and still got a B+. However i did pull an all nighter for the final, and midterm.
He sometimes goes off on tangents and has an erratic style, but is very good at encompassing the total picture.
Not easy, but I learned a lot, and he genuinely cares about students.
zzzzzzzzz.... but an easy class

Very difficult class. He is very hard to follow, understand. Lectures were endless. It is basically a graduate-level class. Its okay if it is your only class. If you have one or two others, good luck.

history 366 is like this guy's hobby or something. He makes many unfounded statements, and spends forever going over boring graphs. On the upnote, his tests are not too difficult. But you had better have a lot of patience!
No Comments

If you're serious about your work, then Dr. Brooke will go the extra mile for you.  He's A+ in my book.  I would recommend him to anyone interested in History.  Well repsected in his field, well published, and just generally a nice guy.

One of the best, if not the best professor Ive had in my college career so far. He kept everything in class very simple and basic, but interesting at the same time. He is great at relaying information and super easy to communicate with, as hes always open to questions or concerns you may have. The two books we read were also great. Awesome guy.

Dr. Lerner was absolutely fantastic. He did not assign a textbook but rather 3 short novels to read. He did an amazing job of engaging with the class during his lectures and was so fun to be around. He does not allow technology but you really don't even feel like checking your phone once he gets going. I would highly recommend.
Hilarious, witted, overal fun prof and class. Lectures are just that, no copying from the screen, he talks, you write. no textbook, but few historical novels are to be read.

Professor Lerner created a very conducive learning environment. Welcomed open conversation throughout lecture and was very entertaining, made the hour and a half go by quickly. Grade consists of 4 reaction papers to assigned books, research paper, participation, and final take home exam. Would definitely take him again if had the chance!

Lerner is a good professor and is enthusiastic about teaching history. His lectures are good and informing, if you attend his class. Attendance is not mandatory, but 10% of your final grade. Only had a midterm, paper, and final exam, but he grades very hard on all of those. If your response is not exactly what he is looking for, do not expect an A.

Possibly the best teacher I have ever had. The lectures give everything you need to know. He is kind of a weird guy, but in an endearing sort of way. My TA was a hard grader but the comments were clear and helpful. He is an insane Boston Red Sox fan. I don't care about baseball, but after his class I hate the Red Sox.

Mitch is seriously one of the best teachers I have ever had. He is engaging, interesting, and funny. He is NOT easy, he expects a lot from his students and never denies that but his class was so good that I honestly didn't mind working hard. Take any class he is teaching.

Professor Johnson was amazing. While he certainly does not make getting a good grade easy, his teaching style is so engaging that it does not matter. Highly recommend if you want something interesting yet a bit challenging
Super simple class. He gives online lectures through YouTube-- straightforward and flexible class. Wasn't hard to get an A if you take good notes on the videos.

I really enjoyed this class and this professor. This class was online and was really easy to complete. The lectures are sometimes long, but its really just a matter of how you prioritize that determines how well you will do in his class. Prof. Johnson was super helpful when you reached out to him and would respond to emails the same day.
Asks incredibly ambiguous questions on quizzes that have no value. You come away from each quiz not understanding how you're wrong. Incredibly demoralizing after countless hours of preparation.

This class was very interesting and prof. Koperski was very knowledgeable about the material. Assignments lean heavily on reading and responding to primary historical documents, so only take if you are comfortable with that.

Amanda is accessible outside of class and tries to get to know us. Weekly discussions+quizzes, 4 exams (none are cumulative), one project and everything was open note. There's also 2 extra credit assignments (super short) and she adds a curve.Textbook is recommended but I never used it. Highly recommend for history ge/open option!
She was wonderful throughout the entire semester. I would recommend this class to anyone. She is so helpful, caring, and understanding.

Would instantly take again in a heartbeat. Exams were super easy with no Proctorio so you never have to worry about your privacy. Assignments were all easy if you stayed on top of everything. Overall really caring and definitely tries to get to know us outside class.

I had Amanda Constantine for CSFRST 2374 (History of Twentieth Century Fashion). The course consisted of four midterm exams, weekly Packback, and a wide variety of different types of quizzes and short assessments. The course was conducted online, and the midterm exams were open note/book. Neither the midterm exams nor the quizzes were proctored.

I entered the course three weeks late and she helped me catch up quickly. She is super nice and even gives you her number to contact. One of my favorite teachers I have ever had. Would definitely recommend the class. She is always open to help and the course is interesting for all genders.

Amanda is one of the best instructors I've ever had! I took fashion history and textiles with her. Lectures are very straightforward, usually fill-in-the-blank slides. Tests are medium easy if you take all the notes you're supposed to, she even makes Quizlets to review content in textiles which has been so helpful. Take a class with her if you can!

Amanda is a great professor, she is dedicated to her students learning the material and is very passionate. There are multiple extra credit opportunities throughout the semester. The lectures are very lengthy and often times two in one week. The class consists of four exams, one big project, and then small quizzes throughout. TAKE NOTES!!!

Wow! Prof Constantine was one of the best I've had at OSU. She's so genuine and clearly knows a lot about history. I had her during the whole corona pandemic and she consistently reached out to check in on us and gave lots of EC. Not sure how you couldn't get an A in this. Take this class w her if you're looking for an easy history GE, it's great!

This is my second semester with Prof. Constantine and I loved having her again! CSFRST 2300 is a pretty easy class. Slides are fill in the blank, so attendance is not mandatory but the class is pretty interesting so I didn't ever skip.

She is an amazingly kind and caring professor. She cares a lot about her students and is super down to earth. Textiles is an 8am class which sucks but having her as the professor made it sooo much better. One of the NICEST professors at the university

I loved Professor Constantine. She gave all information from lectures on lecture slides (don't go to class if you don't want to) and made the lectures super interesting. She was super nice and always made sure we were accommodated. I don't have any sisters but I would like her as a sister if that makes sense.

Professor Constantine did a good job of making this class semi-interesting. Lectures are boring but you need the fill in slides for notes, so I wouldn't skip class too often. Exams are hard because you have to memorize a lot of info, but she gives lots of points in HW and Labs so you can still do well. My class was at 8AM which was rough.

great prof just speed up his lectures (he talks a little slow) I never took notes.He is super sweet and understanding if you have any questions or need an extension on anything. Yes his midterm and final were very time consuming, but he gives you 3 days to complete it I found his class nice and interesting he also has some funny comments on things.

Colin was quick to respond to emails and was very helpful in that sense; he clearly wanted his students to succeed in the class. I was often confused when watching the recorded lectures, which was a downside. The final and midterm weren't particularly difficult, just took a lot of time & effort. Not a bad class for a history/global studies GE tho!

The lectures were pretty hard to follow along with at times and the slides could also be confusing, The weekly quizzes were pretty tough despite taking extensive notes. The midterm & final were very time-consuming (9 paragraphs- each about a different topic + 3-page paper). You're also graded on few things, which makes getting an A or high B hard.

I liked Dr. White at first, but during Finals week I asked to take the final exam at a later date because I had contracted Covid-19. I could barely walk let alone take an exam. He told me he did not offer extensions under any circumstances and he did not care about my "excuse". Easy class, mediocre professor who is a little self-obsessed.

I have never been a history interested person or even environmental topics. Professor White makes it very interesting tho, his class was my favorite of my semester classes because of the organization and interesting facts I learned. The class is more independent and there is a final paper but Professor White helped me! He cares about his students.

Took the online version, and although the class is interesting, biggest thing I didn't like how the deadlines had to be at 5 for each lesson. He's a very harsh grader and watching the presentations was hard because he was so monotone. Had a midterm, final, and a final paper--which is worth more than the actual final itself so don't do poor on them.

I took it online and we had two lessons each week, one due Tuesday at 5 and one due Thursday at 5. If you missed one, you had three makeup assignments to do. There was a midterm, final paper, and final exam. Exams weren't bad and the time to take them was flexible if you emailed ahead of time. Received great feedback on the essay rough draft too!

Lecture-heavy, but interesting. Weekly quizzes over reading were super easy if you just skimmed the readings. One midterm that was just a short easy essay, and a short paper as well. Easy class, nice prof overall.

We had three profs for my class; he was the last of the three and deservedly so.  He was a bore in his lectures and tested us on things pretty much solely from the other profs, which made me want to... idk, but it was a bit unfair.  He is funny every once and a while, but overall his weasely characteristics are overwhelmingly offsetting. No likey:(

Quizzes every lecture not only on the material covered that day, but also on the material from the other two professors in this class. The quizzes had very specific information and while there was a general review guide it was hard to study for them due to the large amount of information covered in class. My least favorite section of the class

Lectures were very boring, closed note quizzes at the end of class were very specific, including dates and names of unimportant things. Over explains directions, like if he wants you to work in a group to discuss something for 5 minutes, he'll spend the first 4 minutes saying he wants you to "be working in a group for 5 minutes"

This was a climate change class taught by 3 professors (each prof. taught for a third of the semester) and his section was by far the hardest. His quizzes were really hard and you have to go to class because there is a quiz/assignment every class.

Prof. White was an amazing professor who was very passionate about the subject and kept class interesting. No exams, just a quiz every lecture to make sure you are reading. Overall he was a great professor.

The only problem I have with him or the class is that attendance is mandatory. Every lecture he gives at least 1 quiz question based on the reading which is highly highly recommended and encouraged. Overall I've learned a lot and he is very passionate about the subject.
Very interesting and very easy class. No exams except a final paper.

Dr. Moore was always available to answer questions by email; has a great desire for her students to become knowledgeable in the history of health, medicine, and disease. The only downside was the amount of reading, be prepared to spend at least 3 hours outside of class. Encouraged students to participate in class discussions.

Dismissive of opinions that differ from his, and grades students harshly if one disagrees with him publicly.  Office visits are useless unless one is already predisposed to agree with his points of view.

Likes to comment on contemporary politics, and is a cheerleader for the Left.

Avoid if possible.

Boring, confusing lectures. Grading was difficult and unfair. Your grade is only based on 2 exams and 1 short paper. Also, he is a stickler about phones in class. He even goes out of his way to make examples of students using their phones.  Not sure how he expects us to make it through his lectures without being able to text occasionally.

Professor McMahon knows a lot about the Vietnam War. He actually protested the war during the 60s. The class was easy and interesting. If you have trouble staying awake in lectures he will probably put you to sleep at sometimes but he is decent.
Dr. McMahon is an expert on the topic of vietnam war. But he does not translate into good teaching in class. Basically jumps around a lot, leaving us lost. Also a hard grader on papers and exams.
Really boring. He knows a lot and has been published several times, but he does not translate well into the teaching setting.
DO NOT take his class!!

Great lecturer, unquestionably an expert on U.S. foreign policy. Does assign a lot of reading, which I found interesting, but it could be rough if the subject matter doesn't interest you. Assignments are pretty much straightforward as long as you do the reading. I feel like I have a much better grasp of 20th century history for taking his class.

really interesting lecturer - is  always willing to help. i agree that he is shaky on grading, need to answer questions exactly how he asks. study lots for tests, know dates - you'll do well. lots of reading, but interesting.

This professor is by far the best history teacher I've ever known. Though I'm sad that he finally left UF after a 20+ year tenure, I'm also happy that he's gotten a very respectful position at Ohio State- which, of course, has a much better history dept. As I can see from some of the previous comments, he obviously deserved better students as well.
A condescending jerk.  He's nice from the podium, but stay away from his office.  A little smarmy.
Enjoyed lectures.  Easy readings.  Friendly, kind, amusing.
No Comments

McMahon is very interesting and gives very indepth lectures.  He's fair on his grading but his clarity and expectations for tests and papers can be a little shakey sometimes. Make sure you study hard for tests and don't miss a single page in the reading! I would probably take him again.
Awesome class- this guy knows his stuff-- not too tough on grading-- just show up and be prepared to take lots of notes.

A brilliant man, though not the greatest teacher.  Talking to him 1-on-1 is much better.  If you take any of his classes, try to plan for the rest of your schedule to be light.  He requires a lot of reading, and fairly in depth papers on the books.
he's boring, but the class was ok.
No Comments

First semester teaching on campus, but was very good. Lectures were good and will get better with time. Course content was very interesting, lectures and readings. Cares about students. Class was small and discussion was encouraged. Midterm and Final were good and fairly graded. No quizzes.
There is a lot of weekly reading you must do for this course so it took up a lot more time than I was planning this class to take. Lenient about dead lines and easy grading!

Her lectures are literally all over the place I have no idea what is EVER going on . Her exams are over hundreds of textbook pages which is too much memorization when you aren't well guided on the "story" of history and what's important to understand

Shes actually the most perfect professor I have ever been graced with. She has taught me so much and makes herself so available to other students. If you need help she is the kindest person in the world and makes you feel validated

Prof. Conklin showed a genuine interest in her students and was always willing to help. She was extremely understanding when I had to miss class and made sure I could make everything up. The class isn't easy but I learned so much that I really enjoyed it. There's a lot of reading from the book but most times you can get away with a good skim.

Professor Conklin is a really nice lady and was willing to help especially if you visited during office hours. Her grading is a little ambiguous as mentioned in other ratings. Exams are a little tough but its a history course since 1500 and a lot of material to remember. Lots of textbook reading and 2 other books but overall not too bad!

very good professor overall, grading is a little confusing (check + vs. check - ?) very helpful if you visit office hours; lectures are very important and lots of reading before class but not much other homework, one paper overall and midterm and final are all written; difficult course but worth it in the end!

Dr. Conklin is wonderful- provides interesting readings and facilitates class discussion well. She genuinely wants to help her students succeed- she was even willing to read rough drafts of the final research paper and offer comments. Great prof.

Not a bad teacher, pretty lenient on grading, allows you to turn in stuff late with legitimate reasons. Don't expect a lot of feedback on writing (what does check + mean?) but like I said a fair grader. Reading the book helps a lot for tests as she tends to go over minor details in lecture.

very nice lady and was more than willing to help students if necessary. but her lectures were boring because its like she was just reading information off a cheat sheet. lots of reading for this class.she wasnt too hard of a grader but exams covered an awful lot of material

She's a very nice woman, and is helpful and fair. The lecture parts of her class are always enjoyable and informative, and even though it was a women's history class, Mrs. Conklin made sure to focus on the "history" aspect of the subject. She also allowed and encouraged a lot of discussion, which is nice, and it always went well.
Prof Conklin is very well spoken and easy to follow. She is very generous in her grading and is helpful outside of the classroom!

Answers email all the time, especially when something is due, even late before a test.  Very personable.  A few contreadictions with the textbook, but I'd be more worried if there were none.  Glad I took the class and hope I have her again.

I honestly have never written a review about a professor online, but I felt it was necessary with Professor Irwin. In my three years of undergrad, I have never been spoken to in such a demeaning way by a professor. He belittles his students, and is not at all adaptable to their needs. He very rarely provides notes, and does not teach.

Irwin's 3045 online entails 45 minutes of lecture videos, a 25 question quiz (3 attempts with repeating questions), 75 pages of academic articles, and a 700 word discussion post per week. Final paper, no exam. It's a lot of work, but he gives GREAT feedback and has clear guidelines. Good personality in lecture, would take again, but pref in person.

Mr. Irwin is definitely my favorite professor at Ohio State. He makes History interesting and points out a lot of things I never would've thought about otherwise. History 2001H is my favorite class I've taken at OSU, and has even made me consider picking up a minor in History. That being said, I had to work really hard in his class, lots of reading

Loved the material, but there was too much outside work. Very reading-heavy and quizzes to take before every class, but those were easy IF you took your time reading (quizzes also had unlimited attempts). However, he was a tough essay grader. Every class is purely discussion based, so if you're not one to talk, better avoid this one.

I really wish I hadn't taken this course. Prof. Siegel downplayed her expectations for the midterm and was passive aggressive with the class after those expectations weren't met. It was very hard to stay engaged with her lectures. This class should have been interesting, but was just stressful.

If you are great at grammar your golden but I feel she focuses on it way to much and is very disrespectful, demeaning, and will assume you put little effort in a paper you slaved over for weeks. Even when I have the paper checked by the writing center (twice) she will criticize their changes so lose lose. If you struggle with grammar stay away!
Flat out lies to you, her instructions say one thing but she grades based on different criteria.

Professor Siegel knows her stuff. HOWEVER, lectures are insanely long and she doesn't express her ideas in a very clear way. Your grade will solely depend on the TA, which in my experience was the worst. You need to be a good note-taker and be able to keep focus for an hour and a half with super bad slides provided.

Seems very nice, but I'm not a fan of her lecture style. She uses elaborate vocabulary and sentences that make it hard to follow while writing notes. Exams and papers are fairly easy depending on your TA. The material is a little confusing at times and she doesn't upload slides, just vague "outlines".

Professor Siegel gives very interesting lectures although they can be off topic at points. She really knows her stuff about European history and her office hours are great for clarification! Expect to be reading for about an hour per week if you're going for a good grade.

I do not like her lecture style. She provides an outline with hardly any info on it for notes but then rambles on incredibly long and complex sentences with unnecessary details about every historical event. Way too much info given so it is hard to keep up with notes. Your grade will depend on how your TA grades, but testsand papers  were reasonable

She is really knowledgable about the subject. Lectures are pretty long and you have to pay attention, but the information is clear and interesting. Gives you a study guide before exams with questions on it that are helpful to prepare. Not a bad class at all if you enjoy history

I personally do not like her lecture style. She stumbles over words a lot and says 'um' too. Her power points don't align with what she's talking about. She covers so much info in 50 min. the with the lack of good power points its impossible to take good notes. There is a lot of reading, too much I think. She has a condescending, stand-offish way

Though her lectures are long, if you enjoy history and the intelligence community, they are enjoyable. Be sure to be involved in class discussions and go to her office hours. She has a lot of experience in her field.

TERRIBLE TEACHER. YOU WILL SIT IN HER LECTURE FOR 5 MINUTES AND LOSE ATTENTION. There is literally no structure to the content of the class, and her Powerpoints contain little to no information... basically listening to an oratory of everything that has happened in the world in the past 100 years. PLUS THE TESTS ARE IMPOSSIBLE! DO NOT TAKE!!!!!
Great class, good lecturer.  Professor Siegel made the subject come alive.

avoid this class, her wealth of knowledge is amazing, and she reminds you of it. study guides are useless as she only tests on 1/20 of what is on them. She rambles on about misc. tangents which do nothing more than encourage naps in class.

Really enjoyed this class. She's traveled for her research and has lots of pictures and stories to go along with the lectures. She puts lecture outlines online, but these contain almost no information, takes attendance every day.

Good God, unless you enjoy napping in class, avoid this class at all cost. The teacher rambles a lot and while she is helpful and certainly knowledgeable in her field of study, I cannot stay awake to save my life. The readings are manageable but ain't nobody got enough cash lying around to buy all those books. Just. NO. Don't enroll.

Class was an endless barrage of information, to the point where it was almost impossible to take good notes.  The sheer amount of information thrown at us in class made it incredibly difficult to study for exams, even with study guides.  I felt that I learned more about WWI/WWII in general than I did about intelligence.

Really knowledgeable on subjects, and is willing to help you if you go to office hours. She goes quickly and you don't get a break, so get some caffeine before class. I recommend typing up your notes so when you need to make flashcards for the midterm and final, you can search for the terms easier. You should really like history to take the class.
There was a lot of material to cover, and it was hard to take notes and keep up pace w/ the material presented. Other than, that, not a bad professor.

Very clear and concise during her lectures.  She did not offer a break, but she generally stopped lecture early.  We watched 3 films during lecture, and took our midterm during a lecture time.  As a result there were only 16 lectures to cover the entire 20th Century.  As long as you come to class and pay attention you will do well in her class.

Seems to be unorganized at times.  At times she contradicted the text, which leads to ambiguity when exam time rolls around (didn't know whether to give the "right" answer from the book or her "right" answer).

Class is a constant barrage of information with no chance to take good notes, due to lots of material being given. NO BREAKS which leads to fatigue and sleep due to constant rambling. Material is good but it seems to slant to a her bias view of history.

Really knowledgeable but FLIES through material. Will leave you in the dust if you pause a second to write down some notes. Her tests are hard and the TAs for this class seemed to be on different planets when it came to grading. Huge amount of reading (but not tested over) and only 2 tests and a paper to cover the whole 20th century.

She knows a lot about history, only her teaching style is boring, she gives no breaks, just a straight lecture until the bell rings.  Stay awake, take a lot of notes, I suggest bringing a computer for notes, because she does NOT stop talking, does not write on the board, and does not let you know when transistinoing to the next topic.

Not much new information. Grading was chaotic. Must follow instructions to the letter on papers or you'll lose big points. (things like cover page, page #'s, structure of bibliography). On tests you have to go beyond the instructions to get  a good grade. Never know what she expects till after the fact. I wouldnt take this one again.
Knows a lot about History.  The class was boring, but easy.  She didn't give any tests, which was awesome.  I recommend her if you HAVE to take the class.

This prof is tough but totally fair and WAY interesting.  If you are not into learning, she might not be right for you, but it's obvious that she puts a lot of time and thought into her teaching.  It's nice to have someone up there who expects a lot from you, but gives a lot of herself as well.
A very intense course. This class has a TON of information!! She is very willing to help out if you take the time to visit her during office hours (especially before midterms and finals).

I don't know if its the class and she has to follow a ciriculum, but class is pretty boring.  She is pretty nice and encourages a lot of participation but can snap at you a little.  Be prepared to read a TON!!!!!
informative class, but her teaching style is a bit stiff.

You definitely need to pay attention in class and ensure that youre taking notes. She was kind, but sometimes rubbed me the wrong way because some of the stuff she said conflicted with stuff in my other history class which was backed by primary sources. The quizzes she gave out were only five questions, each worth 20pts so it was easy to do poorly

Professor Knight was a really amazing teacher with her lectures being not only interesting but packed with information. Prof knight was very knowledgable on her subject as well. I really enjoyed this class, even though it was only a 3 hour period once a week, it was undoubtedly my favorite class of my freshman year!

I had Dr. Knight for an African American history class at CSCC. She was very thorough and her teaching was awesome. You write your own notes and go over them in class, it helps you learn a lot more. She is very knowledgeable and helpful and I learned a lot in her class. There is a lot of work but nothing hard and it was worth it!

Did NOT like her. Made the class WAY harder than it should have been for a gec. Thinks it's an african american studies class with an emphasis on english and grammar. Did not learn any history at all. Very disappointed. Have to write a paper every week and her lectures were about how to use citations every week, not history.

Worst teacher I ever had. She assigned a paper every week, and changed the syllabus 3 times in the quarter. She expects all of us to see her in office hours, even if you have an A in the class. She threatens to lower your grade if you do not attend the office hours to talk about your papers. I will NEVER take her again. Shes full of herself.

not that bad. She has essays during the quarter, 7 pop quizzes (2 dropped), you're allowed to miss 2 classes, her lectures are taught well and the book is a re-enforcer to the material. There are 5 debates, but they're really easy. She's helpful if you ask. I'm a student that normally gets a/b grades and she wasn't hard at all, just do the work
Was not bad got a B+ without trying.  She didn't even have a final we just had to write a paper.

Felice Knight is the worst teacher i ever had, she is useless and doesnt help student. she doesnt know anything about the history of Africa. The highest grade she gave on midterm was 69 i hate her. i got 89.5 and she gave me B+ intead of giving me A- . Dont take her class Avoid her.Bad.... Bad...Bad Ta
I am taking her for history 121. She made the class hell, she is full of herself and out of tough. Void her else she will give you C or worse D.
Just the grader but had to leave a nice rating.

Ben was a good TA. He brought interesting points of view to the conversation and treated delicate periods of American history with the respect they deserved. He does expect you to participate in the discussion, so make sure to participate. Don't worry about being wrong or unsure about topics, he will correct you and add it to the conversation.

weekly discussion sessions were fine, except he expects students to know everything about history. Main problem is he grades like a nitpicker, and looks for anything possible to knock you down. Does not give good feedback on exam essays either, just says generic statements that in the long term are not helpful.
This class entails a ton of reading that can oftentimes be really daunting. That said, Prof. is super passionate and helpful when it comes to grading papers and giving feedback.

The class is largely discussion, so attendance matters; however, the discussions are engaging and based on the reading assignments. The class is reading heavy. Sometimes they can be difficult, but the material is super interesting if youre into feminism and history. Shes great at fostering discussion and is very open minded to new ideas.

This professor led me and a friend of mine to believe we could take this class without any prior experience with WGSS. She was not at all helpful when you ask questions, gave super vague answers and not guidance, and the readings were almost impossible to decipher. She would berate us about not "giving good answers" on the discussion posts. AVOID!

I was a bit intimidated at first because she seemed like she might be very strict on things, but I couldnt have been more wrong. She is extremely knowledgeable about World History and was very organized making it very easy to learn in her class even though it was mainly lectures. She is also lenient when it comes to grading in this class.

Anyone whom gave her a negative review honestly didnt do the work. She is very knowledgeable in her field amazing interring lectures. Very kind and helpful. Not only does she care she wants you to succeed. Do your part and you will pass. Honored to be her student. Take her, show up, participate, do your homework and hello A oh and visit her office

Lecture-heavy, a bit dry as well, but if you're into history she's very knowledgeable and you'll learn a lot. One in-class midterm that seems daunting at first but is essentially just identification. One take-home midterm and a short paper too. Manageable prof, relatively easy A.

Dr. Hathaway is a nice lady, but can be a real stickler on grammar and writing which can make the class seem really hard a times, though I felt like I walked away with a decent grade. I liked the field trips around campus. There is a couple of papers involved, and reading responses on the book. The text book is boring but a must have for homework.

I want to say I was interested in the class when I signed up for it, but I found that it could be pretty boring sometimes. She is very knowledgeable on the subject and it shows in her lectures. Just one midterm, a paper and a take home final. There are some mandatory attendance days that factor into your final grade.

Social Movements in Muslim World. She was very friendly and surprisingly up-to-date with the times. Not a dinosaur. Rarely used the book. Lectures are online. Just go to class for discussions. Midterm was difficult and required memorization, but final was take-home. I enjoyed her. The class, meh.

Hathaway is a boring lecture... attended recitations only for attendance pts, & download the pdfs from lectures off carmen & read wiki articles, & did just fine. study guides are helpful, but the kind that have LOTS of info on them, whereas she only tests you on a couple things from it, so you have to memorize a bunch of stuff that goes to waste.

Ottoman History. Pretty good teacher, has a tendency to ramble but knows her stuff. Class is most interesting to people who are history majors or middle east focus. As far as history classes go, it was pretty easy. One small paper, midterm and final.
My only complaint was that you really had to write real fast while taking notes.... other than that... she was good
I didn't go to class that often, but when I did she made the lecture very easy to follow. Easy midterms and finals with very helpful study guides.
very clear on what you need to know.  helpful reveiw
I didnt read a page in the book, never went to class (besides required recitation) and got an A. Fair/easy midterm and final! WHOO HOO

Strangely resembles Kathy Griffin. Very boring class. She is very helpful though, but be prepared for some TA's who don't understand English very well.  She also makes you read some stupid books that don't really pertain much to the coursework.
No Comments

Ottoman History. Very good class and I recommend it for anyone interested in the Middle East or the Balkans. She makes sure you are well read and covers more than just who did what when. I really enjoyed the Turkish food on the last day.
This class was not too difficult, and the grading and due dates were fair. However, this professor took a really long time to grade our papers, so you never really knew where you stood in the class.

Its not so much the material she teaches or the work (though her grading of papers seems arbitrary) but her attempts to indoctrinate students. I've had many professors who have liberal views and do their best to teach mostly unbiased, but She seemed to make no effort to withhold her opinions from the classroom. Have a dissenting opinion? It's wrong

Plenty of extra credit, however did not learn a thing in the class. All of the grade is weighted on four separate papers, attendance and participation. The class itself is extremely dry and leads to long lectures and painful reading. You have to at least skim through the reading as she likes to throw in some written responses to assigned readings.

Adrienne was so great! I was not very interested in taking this class initially; I only needed it to complete a GEC. However, after exploring the "holes" in American history with Adrienne, I came to enjoy the class each day I attended. The books for the class are excellent resources and if you read, participate and listen, you can/will get an A!

Adrienne cares so much about History and her passion shows through in her teaching. She has high expectations and makes you work for your grade, but she's the type of person that you want to do well for.  Taking this class taught me more than just women's history...it made me a better student and a better person. A+ teacher.

Adrienne is very sweet and tries very hard to make her class interesting. She is enthusiastic about the subjects she teaches and offers an abundance of help outside of class and plenty of extra credit opportunity. Like...A LOT. Take home midterms and exam PROJECTS. Super great prof if you like to do work outside of class.

She's a pretty great professor. Very interested in her topic and it shows. Quite a bit of reading involved but if you keep up and pay attention you should do fine. Very helpful when you have questions and always willing to meet outside of class, even if you can't make her office hours.

I took his online class for History 1681, and it was absolutely wonderful.
Rather than use lectures, he gave us materials to read--telling us to interpret these lesson as we will.

Never take her class. She's the worst professor I have ever had-- she's horrible with technology, ignores your emails, is rude when you try to talk with her, and creates 0 lecture material to coincide with her disorganized discussions. Her entire class is based on 3 papers, and she gives no guidance on what her expectations are.

Dr. Shaw isn't necessarily a poor teacher, but she talks in circles and it's very easy to get lost during her lectures because she trails off topic. She assigns many readings and essays, some in back-to-back weeks, and she is very disorganized. Once she changed the book assignment for a class three days before the class. The book was over 200 pages

Dr. shaw is an ok teacher. Shes great at answering any questions you have about the material . Her lectures are boring, she has 2 exams. ALL essay questions so if you mess up on one part that'll hurt you. YOU HAVE TO READ THE TEXTBOOKS ASSIGNED

Dr. Shaw is an incredible professor. In order to do well, you need to take lecture notes and read the material. She does not go over all material in class, but you still need to know it in order to excel on exams and papers. In her lectures, she can go off into different topics, but all add to the course. She is a fair grader and amazing person.

She is knowledgeable on the subject, but she is often contradictory and vague in her explanations. You never know what she actually wants you to do for the papers, which are your entire grade. She also grades extremely hard for the course material.

Dr. Shaw is phenomenal! She pushes her students to think beyond personal opinion to engage the material in scholarly, yet palatable, manner. If you are looking for an easy way out, don't take her course. But if you are looking to advance your skills as an intellectual, then this is the professor for you! I use her principles to this day! EXCELLENT!
One of the worst professors I have every had at OSU.  She rambles and grades extremely hard.  Her grading is very subjective and if you don't write what she believes then your wrong.

She took a subject that I had no interest in and made it bearable however we discuss the same topic for the entire quarter. But once you meet her you'll understand why she chose that topic. Other instructors like critical analyses but she wanted papers to be non-biased from students. I felt like I could never meet her expectations with the papers.

Gotta say, loved the class-great readings, great discussions, but it will NOT be spoonfed- learning is active; you get out of it what you put into it.  I'd gladly take her again, as would everyone I've ever talked to about her.
I had really looked forward to this class.  Unfortunately, Shaw was often unprepared and had difficulty leading productive discussions.  Too bad.

Ms. Shaw is an interesting southerner who will barley read your papers, and grade them easily.  Class is worthless and counts only for attandance, other than that it is a waste of perfectly good frisbee time
Mrs. Shaw seemed more interested in her book than our class.  The material was not thought-provoking or anything.
No Comments
No Comments

The class itself is not horrible. If you are interested in the Vietnam War you will definitely get something out of this course. However, the professor is so bland. I could not listen to the lectures as he would literally read a script and it was so obvious. Its not entertaining and feels like you are watching paint dry.

An absolutely fantastic professor to have, not only is he extremely respected by the university, but he receives equal respect from his students. Lectures consist of large discussions that engage the entire class, meaning it's necessary to do the readings for it. The readings are worth it simply because of how fun it is to participate in his class.

Not a difficult class. Staley is a great professor that engages the class. Attendance wasn't mandatory but was for a grade as well as participation in discussions in class. Staley wasn't a hard grader and provided great feedback, overall he cared about students and their improvement throughout the course.
Amazing prof, great mentor, so helpful to students and all around great person. Highly recommend taking one of his classes or just getting to know him in general.

Dr. Staley is a great professor and is invested in his students. This class was 100% discussion-based and participation is mandatory. There are weekly readings and 3 papers over the course of the semester-so pretty easy. He is a pretty tough grader though, especially for an intro level class.

I love Professor Staley's class. He keeps everyone engaged in lectures which feel more like conversations than lectures. He is very wise and funny. This class is easy if you show up to class and pay attention which isn't hard with Professor Staley's teaching style. I definitely recommend taking this course.

Dr. Staley is a wonderful History professor. He genuinely cares about his students and their opinions. He is willing to go deeper in the class material, and asks thought provoking questions. Participating in class discussions are mandatory for this class, however they are always fun and informative. I would definitely recommend this class!
Made the subject really interesting. Staley is one of the most engaging and interesting lecturers I've ever had.

Staley is my favorite professor I've had at Ohio State. He loves the material and his job. He really changed how I study History. It's not just memorization. He sparks meaningful, interesting discussions and pushes us to search for the "Why" in every situation. He's a great Professor, I'd highly recommend him (even if History is not your major).
He seems very interested in history but is unable to keep the class interested! Look around the room and half the class is asleep or playing an iphone game at any given time!

One of the best professors I've had so far at OSU.  I was a History major as a "fallback" and had a mild interest in it but Staley re-sparked my love of History.  His class isn't simple, you still have to do readings and show up and participate, but he isn't trying to fool you but see what you know. Really nice and helpful guy

He is unorganized! Halfway through the semester let us retake quizzes - but would not let us go back and retake the first half. Does NOT round and will not work with you in trying to improve your score. A tough grader for literally no reason, this is a GE course. Gives everyone 4/5 on discussion posts and thinks he is better than you

Prof Sokolsky is pretty good. There was a lot of work in the beginning, but it was pretty manageable after the first couple of weeks. The content was interesting, and as long as you do the work you should do fine.

Mark is very clear at what he wants. He is a fair grader and gives great feedback. His class is just 3 quizzes that were simple if you prepared for them since he gives you specifically what was on it. The research paper is really what determines your grade and he gives good feedback. The lectures were dry and discussionparticipation was required.

Mark is the best history teacher I've ever had. Lectures are very clear and organized. He is very nice and will do everything he can to make sure you succeed. He gives thorough and detailed feedback on your paper and quizzes. Mark is a fair grader, so as long as you put some effort in this class you'll get a decent grade. Highly recommended!

Mark is an awesome professor when it comes to taking a GE class and doing well in it. He is very helpful and gives you awesome feedback. He responds to your emails and is there whenever you need him. Would take again. His instructions are very clear and you know exactly what to do for every assignment. He also makes outlines of the lecture slides.

I was sad when Mark's class ended. He actually made me interested in Russia. The exams were all essay based and stressful at times if you didn't put effort into the class. The papers were so-so, but he was a fair grader. He was so nice and so engaged in his subject. He took attendance and pushed everyone to participate. All around a great guy.

Mark was great. He is smart and knowledgeable. His lectures were engaging and easy to follow. He's also very nice and pretty easy going. The class was very fair; just put a little effort into it and you'll get a good grade.

I took this class over the summer and really found it interesting. Mark is very helpful and a really good teacehr. His grading is fair and his lectures are easy to folow. And not to mention, his good looks makes the time goes by really fast  :)
He makes the lectures fun and interesting, while never showing bias when the topics become political. Very reading intensive, but not a difficult at all.

Dan the Man was my advisor and my teacher. Super reachable during office hours, always ready to have a chat about whatever you're interested in, super respectful of others, and a really wonderful human being He loves what he teaches and he is a teacher you can build a strong bond with Take any class you can with him, you will learn so much
I've taken three of his classes, and they were all amazing. He assigns a ton of reading, and not all of it is interesting but it's all really informative.

He's obviously very passionate about the subject and that alone makes his class very fun to go to. He doesn't believe in textbooks, but instead uses several independent books to talk about. They're all quite cheap, so no complaints there. Overall his class is the one I'm most excited to go to.

He seems like he would be a cool guy but is a terrible professor. He assigns heavy reading every day despite the fact that many students are taking other classes that require reading as well. You have to take a quiz EVERY DAY. This is the worst grade Ive ever received. Ive done better in harder classes because of his methods.

This class requires you to read. He assigns you 6 books at the beginning of the semester and you have quizzes everyday over these books. Despite the amount of reading, I enjoyed his class and loved him as a teacher. If you can handle the reading, he makes his lectures easy and interesting. I would take him again if the class required less reading.

Assigns 6 novels through the whole semester. Gives reading quizzes every class period (mostly). This class is an easy A IF you read the books. Books are boring usually but its not hard to read them. Very nice professor, just expect a ton of reading.

He is very nice and his class is soooo easy! You do have to read the books to pass the quizzes but there are no tests. If you know anything about history, then you will definitely pass and if you read, you will make an A.

In Dr. Vandersommers class, there is a lot of reading. Yet, he manages to make the reading manageable and interesting, even if the book is not interesting at all. His lectures are short and to the point. You can tell he takes a personal interest in each student he teaches. He is extremely approachable and easy to talk to if you ever need anything.

One of the best professors I've had yet Cours consisted of plenty of reading don't fall behind on reading in order to keep a good grade it is essential. Less of a lecture class but may lecture from time to time. He really cares for you and wants to see you succeed through his teachings much was learned and class was very interesting  5stars

Dan is a smart guy and has good intentions for teaching. However I do not recommend taking his class if you have a busy lifestyle. His class requires unreasonable hours of reading for a gec intro based course, which I personally think is nuts.

Take him! He is an awesome teacher. He teaches history based on 5 normal books (not a textbook) that you have to read and take quizzes on every class, but they are simple if you've done the reading. The class is discussion based, you don't take ANY notes. No midterms/final, he doesn't believe in them. Informal, 2pg paper. Best history class.

Super helpful, I had him for a night class so I was worried I wouldn't be engaged. He totally reenergized my love of history. Interesting class, allowed for a lot of discussion. I definitely encourage anyone who doesn't typically like history to take it from him--he'll change your mind!
Really looked out for the students and made it easy to understand.

Only a TA for now but a good one. While his class was on the easy side, he also showed a deep interest in history and wanting us to succeed. Every week he would e-mail us reminders on assignments and what we were doing for class. Probably the best TA I've had so far.
No Comments

I took this as a condensed 4 week online SUcourse: the lecturers were prerecorded and felt very informal, like he was in the room telling stories. There was extensive reading involved for the essays and discussion posts as they spanned lectures and textbook. Overall 3 essays due (one a book essay), and an extra credit fourth. I ended with a 101%

I had the privilege of taking HIST 2402 w/ Prof. Schultz, and he's probably the funniest professor I've had to date. His grading policies are clear, and the assignments themselves are not difficult. His posted lecture notes are incredibly detailed and ultimately allow you to just show up and listen. I would love to take him again, 10/10.

This class is not an easy A. Ryan is a good professor for that he knows what he is talking about. There is a lot of reading (2 books and the textbook), but I got away without reading the textbook. There are 6 papers which are quite lengthy and challenging. You are graded on attendance and the papers. He is a tough grader. Again, NOT AN EASY A.
Lots of reading but over all great class
Great Prof! 100% recommend. He cares a lot about the subject and it makes the lectures really interesting.
Really charismatic guy. Cares a lot about the material and wants his students to as well. Answers every single question to the best of his ability. Unique sense of humor, but still really funny.

Overall, he's a pretty cool guy and really cares about the subject material. However, there's a weird disconnect between the simplicity of the general work and the difficulty of the exams. Our's are take home, which is nice, but the fact that the essay prompts are harder than some of the prompts for actual essays is weird considering it is a G.E.
strict teacher
Not a easy class.

Boring lecture. Don't take this class. Take too much time. Not helpful and did't learn a thing from the lectures. Tough grader. More than 10% students get academic misconduct due to the paper or exam.
Took his class simply to fulfill the GE requirement, but ended up really enjoying it. You can tell he loves the topic he's teaching and is truly there to help.

2 3-page reports, weekly online discussions, weekly short answer questions. Extra credit assignment worth 5% extra on final grade. I hate history and writing, just took for GE yet still pasted with nearly 100%. Good amount of work, but worth it for the professor's grading. Full credit is almost always given

There is a level of arrogance that I have grown to despise with John Perry he does put time into his lectures and tries to come off as caring but once you get further into its course it's true colors begin to show and then once you get to his Final exam it really begins to fall apart.

I didn't find the papers beneficial to my learning, and the grading was very harsh. For the amount of effort this prof puts into his lectures and the emails riddled with typos, it makes me cringe to think of what tuition costs when you get classes like these...

He assigns long papers and takes off points for silly, subjective things. The recorded lectures he uploaded to Carmen were atrocious--he was clearly reading from a paper and messed up every other word. It was beyond distracting. A mediocre prof at best with unreasonable expectations. Would not recommend unless you have no other option.
Teacher is way too hard for a GE. I tried so hard on everything and put a lot of effort, more than I should have, and still got B's on all papers. Take a different class or a different professor.

Went into this class because it sounded interesting and I genuinely had interest in the topic, but like the other reviewer I just wanted it to be over by the end. He made the material unbearable and he grades way too hard for a GE. Also, he is pretty arrogant about his intelligence. This class ended up being the biggest pain in my ass.
He makes the class uninteresting and grades very harshly. I came into this class very interested in the subject and at the end I just wanted it to be over.

Took this class to take care of a GE. Overall hes a good professor but your grade is determined entirely by 3 exams which are graded harshly. Do NOT buy the textbooks he tells you to buy, you will be fine as long as you just go to class and take good notes.

Steve Hunt is an good guy who is very passionate and educated on the course material. The class itself basically consists of watching movies and Steve lecturing before and after them. The grading is based ONLY on three exams, each worth 100 points. These exams are very subjective, so take great notes in class so you have the perfect wording.

Great class for GE credit dont need textbook he goes over what is needed to write for the 3 exams. Actually repeats himself so much it was annoying, clearly lectures class same every semester. Final grade will depend on how tedious the TAs grade.

Steve is a pretty good lecturer. The material isn't difficult, but the three exams each consist of three essay questions. These exams are also the only grades you receive in the class. He doesn't use Carmen often, only to post the lecture slides prior to exams. Frequently pauses films to lecture. Don't buy the textbook.

Three exams. Three questions each. While he is clear on what is going to be on the exams, there is a lot of verbiage that is expected to be used on the exams. I would recommend going to class, not required but the slides he posts aren't great. Don't get the book. I guess the plus is you see lots of movies but he pauses them to lecture periodically.

Easiest class Ive ever taken. Reiterated exactly what he wanted you to say for the 3 essay based tests. Basically told you the questions also. Definitely dont get the book or bother reading because everything you need to know is told during lecture. Go to class, pay attention and take decent notes and youll get an A

Don't buy the textbook, you won't need it. Lectures are very boring, half of the class skips daily. Watch a movie for a couple days and then listen to Steve give a scripted lecture for an entire class about his poetic thoughts of the movie. The class is easy, just a little painful to sit through. test essays were a little picky but mostly fair.
