As long as you go to class and pay attention (at least somewhat) this class will be pretty easy. Hunt reiterated important aspects in lecture so you knew what to look over for the test. The movies we watched in class were pretty interesting too.

Class is lecture heavy and grade is made up of just three exams. Tests are all essay questions which is annoying but he is very clear in his lectures about what is going to be on tests. Movies that you watch are pretty good but his lectures are long and boring. He says you need the book but you definitely do not. Easy class for non artsy people.

Steve is a great professor and is very passionate about cinema which makes the class interesting for a GE. Don't waste money on the book, I didn't use it once. Everything needed for the exams in from lecture. Make sure you pay attention because the only grades in the class are exams.
Great professor! I took his class for a gen ed. He's funny, smart and really likes to teach this class. I had fun.

Steve is an endearing man who cares about what he teaches. I had him for Intro to World Cinema, his lectures were insightful and clear. Dry at times but now and then there's a funny remark thrown in. Grade is based off of the three exams, so study hard for them. Steve will pretty much tell you what the essay questions will be if you go to lecture.

I enjoyed Intro to World Cinema. Steve did a fairly good job. The class can get boring because of all the technical terms. The TA's grade the exams, and they are tough graders. You must attend class to pass, as you watch the movies (which are covered on the exam) in class.
Attendance isn't mandatory but you do need to show up because you watch films in class and he goes over exactly what you need to know for the exams. Good guy, very funny

One of the easiest classes I have taken. I showed up, watched some old films for an hour, and then left. It gets a little boring at times, but he will repeat over and over whatever information he essentially wants you to regurgitate on the exams. Would recommend as an easy Fine Arts GE.

The only grades in this class are the exams which sucks. The exams are also only three questions and essay based. Lecture is important because all you do is watch movies that he explains. At least attend the lecture before an exam because he will practically give you the three questions that will be asked on the exam.
Prof Hunt doesn't post any grades on carmen, TAS grade extremely hard. i wouldn't recommend this class to anyone. Especially if you like to keep track of your progress.

Prof Hunt is a great and knowledgable professor. His lectures are good and you get to watch a lot of films in the class. The grading is ridiculously hard (TAs grade exams) and extremely unfair. You could turn in the greatest essay response on an exam and get a B-, its extremely confusing and unfair. Also, your entire grade is 3 exams so, be ready.

Generally an easy class. Virtually feeds answers to you in lectures but you need to show up to get them. Class can be quite boring at times, especially the middle part of the course. Powerpoints are basically useless. He seems like a nice guy. Pretty much a guaranteed A/A- if you show up and pay attention to his commentary on the films.

Pretty interesting and fun class. You should go to most lectures to watch the films and pay attention to his comments. Make sure on exams to regurgitate everything he said about the films (he repeats it a lot). Takes forever to grade exams, but it was a big class.

Professor Hunt is a great professor and cares about his students. His lectures can get a bit repetitive but he basically feeds you the answers to his exams if you go to class and listen. I thoroughly enjoyed this class.

Prof. Hunt is one of my favorite teachers ever at Ohio State. The lectures were super engaging and I really enjoyed how passionate Steve was about the topic. The lectures did tend to get pretty repetitive sometimes, but that's only a minor complaint of mine. Prof. Hunt makes it very clear about what he expects on the exam, definitely an easy A

Steven Hunt was a great professor. His tests are fairly easy and he usually tells you what you need to know a few days before the exam. His lectures are slightly fast paced and sometimes it is hard to take notes, and there are very few opportunities for grades with only 3 exams all semester but overall a very good professor.
Steve Hunt is amazing. Thoroughly enjoyed his lectures. He says the funniest things. This man is a gem.

The TAs were tough when grading (2 midterms and the final, which are writing-based), but Professor Hunt was a great instructor. He repeated himself to make sure that what we were watching in films was connected to what we would hear during lectures. I learned a lot, and it was cool to have somebody so passionate teaching us.

He explains what is needed for the exams and is easy to follow because he repeats himself. However, the TA's grade the exams and are tough. It is helpful to use the terms he highlights in class on exams because that is what they are focused on.
He cares about what he is teaching. No homework or tests, just exams.

This is probably my least favorite teacher I've ever had. He's so pompous, so arrogant, and so repetitive. If you'renot stupid, prepare to be treated like you are because Hunt will spoon-feed you information again and again. And you want to actually watch the movies? Forget it. Hunt will interrupt every 30 seconds to ramble and spoil the plot.

Professor Hunt is obviously very passionate about the subject material. He goes over notes in class and then each day in class he reviews the notes from the previous lecture. Book was never used.  His TAs had a very tough grading scale which is difficult when you only have 3 grades for the whole class.
Understanding, will take time to explain things even with 100 plus students, funny in a dad way.

Mr. Hunt always seemed genuinely interested in what he was teaching. I would try not to miss too many classes if any because the questions on the exams are basically the topics he repeats over and over again. Take good notes and study the important points and you should be fine! I had a tough TA and she graded all the exams.

Steve Hunt, although his lectures were quite redundant, is clearly very passionate about the subject and it shows. Tests are very easy as long as you pay attention when he shows videos. Office hours very helpful if you miss any info

Steve is a cool guy and you can tell he's passionate about cinema. His class is really easy, just show up and take notes.   My only qualm is that he constantly interrupts the films. You'll be getting into a movie and he'll pause it to spoil what's about to happen or point out something obvious that just happened. It's infuriating to sit through.

A pretty average professor in my opinion. He's really repetitive in lectures-- spends half an hour reviewing what he covered last time. He also asks open-ended questions and seems to expect you to telepathically know what he wants to hear. Not a bad professor, by any means,  just not the best I've ever had.

If you want to show up to class, take easy notes, never have to read the book, have no homework for an entire semester AND watch movies then this class is for you. Important to go to class, but he gives all necessary information for exams(which isn't a lot) concisely and easy to understand. I would recommend 100% to anyone, I loved it.
Just show up and watch the movies and go to his review sessions. No need to read or buy the book, he explains everything very clearly in class.

Don't bother buying the book. I never took it out of the packaging. Missing lecture is not really an option because the exams are only 3 questions and are from what he tells you during lecture. Easy A if you go and take notes!

Go to class, all of the information is given there. The only grades given are from 3 essay format exams (2 midterms, 1 final). They are easy as long as you pay attention in lecture. Lecture is often repetitive (pay attention to what he repeats its more than likely one of the questions on the exam). Textbook is completely unnecessary.

Great guy, he repeats key points in the lectures and the artists he enjoys the most. He will most likely tests on these subjects as well. Exams were easy, he gives you a list of art work you need to know. He kept taking art pieces off our required list so studying for the exams were even easier.
Very nice and helpful but SUPER boring!! very monotonous voice and very repetitive in his speech. Hard to stay awake in that class so don't take it in the AM.

Really nice guy and is willing to help you. Go to class. Movies he show get boring sometimes. If you miss a class go to his office hours and he will help and even give you the DVD to watch. Only 3 grades, 2 midterms and and final and there three questions. Their easy as long as you pay attention in class and talk to him if you have questions.
Very helpful and clear. Often times repeats himself, but I think he does this to clarify key points.

Nice guy, very passionate and helpful. Go to class, pay attention, and study. Exams are not hard but cover a lot of detailed information and are easy to slip up on if you don't put in the work. Take advantage of his office hours so he knows who you are!
He teaches with passion so he is much more interesting to listen to than some others who are not excited about what they teach. He is very clear and if you come to class and study, easy A.

Steve's a great prof. He points out the important details during lecture and really knows what he's talking about. I took this class just because it fit well into my schedule, but I actually learned a lot. You really do have to go to class and take notes as the powerpoints he posts online wouldn't be enough to study off. Don't buy the book!

Professor Hunt is an excellent teacher and lecturer. He provides you with all the information you need to know. Going to class and taking notes is very important though. Your grade comes from only 3 exams and they are all essays. However, Hunt makes it very clear what is important to know. I almost dropped the course, but am SO happy I didn't.

He really emphasizes the important details for the exams. He only gives three midterms, so you have to do well on them. I didn't study very much but managed to get an A-. Just go to his classes and take very detailed notes, you will do fine on midterms. Films were boring at the beginning but they get interesting later on.

Professor Hunt is very articulate teacher.  His lectures are always on point and he reiterates the necessary information so you know what he is looking for in the essay exams.  The films were well chosen and represent a wide variety of film styles.  The films and lectures always follow the text readings. He doesn't grade the exams,the TA's do- FYI.

Steve is great! Just sit in the front, visit him during office hours, let him know who you are (its enough for participation points), Essay midterms are easy, just PAY a LOT of attention. Loved this class though, Recommend it for GEC and you WILL end up learning something from it

The films ended up actually interesting me and kept me going to class. As long as you take detailed notes you will do fine on the exams which were unfortunately always essays, so your hand gets a little tired by the end. If you go to class and take notes then you probably don't need to waste money on the text book.

The movies we watched were interesting and historically relevant. He's a good lecturer. Exams are all essays, so they are challenging, and not enough time was given to answer the questions. We had 45 mins out of a 1 hr, 48 min class to answer three essay questions. Unreasonable if you ask me.

I thought this class would be interesting because I love movies, but this class is pretty boring. I have no issue with Steve. He's a nice, helpful guy, but my TA was horrible, unfair, and an absolute moron. She graded exams incredible tough and completely unfairly and refused to correct obvious grading mistakes.

Classes are boring but you have to go because attendance is 10% of your grade. 3 exams, essay format. Overall, very easy if you go and take detailed notes. Took the second exam hungover and pulled out a 95. Easy GEC and good if your interested in movies.
Do NOT get textbook. I didn't open it at all. Very nice teacher, very helpful. I highly recommend him. Go to class, pay attention, and you should do just fine. And his lectures aren't boring.
very interesting character and lecture delivery. impressive knowledge. i'll miss his hilarious wording. "nuances of bark!"
Class is OK.  Seems like the class lasts forever.  Prof Hunt's lectures are pretty boring.  I only went to class about 8 times and still pulled out a C.  DO NOT GET TEXT!!!!

I love movies so I thought this class would be awesome. It was pretty good, but Steve lectures and lectures and lectures.... and it's INCREDIBLY boring. I managed to fall asleep almost every day. He sounds like he is reading out of the textbook, the way he talks. I would recommend him though, because the class was easy and the material interesting.
It was an interesting class, and very easy to get a good grade in- its a good GEC class!

He can lecture for the better part of two hours and students will glean perhaps 30 seconds of useful information while he repeats the same phrases endlessly. Watching him labor through his ultimately useless lesson plan is akin to watching an aging athlete still try to compete at the top level. In the end, you just want someone to let him rest.

Steve was the nicest guy, and was more than willing to help anyone who came to him.  However, his lectures were overly wordy and repetitive, which I feel really detracted from the class.  I really liked the class, however, and the movies he picked were fantastic for what he was trying to teach us.  He really knows his stuff, as well.

good professor.  exams are essay form, but they aren't that bad because he gives you a studyguide that is an outline of how you should answer exam questions.  he tells you everything you need to know about the films you watch so my best advice is show up and pay attention and you'll do fine.  you dont need the text book.

He was a pretty decent professor. He liked to lecture for a long time and people would fall asleep but you just have to catch part of it because he says the same thing over and over again. He gives you handouts for the movies and you just have to study those and remember stuff he says in class to get an easy A.
I liked this class a bunch, and I love Hunt's slight Canadian accent.

Prof. Hunt definitely knew the material and if you paid attention and took good notes it is easy to get an A in this class.  He is rather wordy during lectures, though, and I sometimes was bored.  If you pay attention he tells you basically word for word what you will need to know for tests.  He is a very good teacher in this aspect!
Hunt kicks butt! This guy is amiable, knowledgeable and straightforward. There is NO WAY to get a bad grade in this class. In my opinion. But I'm a medieval art loving dork so keep this in mind:)
I would take another class of his. He went over material very thoroughly. I don't think having to know the dates and inspirational reasons were "minor" details.
I really enjoyed the class, he made his expectations clear. He keeps the class interesting and I didn't get bored at lecture. I would recommend this class with him for a visual arts GEC.

I think he's a walking Art History encylcopedia. Great, interesting class. Just make sure you go to lectures and make flashcards, or you'll drown.  Sooo much cool stuff, though, and Prof. Hunt was really good at communicating a passion for the material.

I really liked his class, he gave lots of information and went over it multiple times so there was no way you couldn't know what he was expecting.  Take lots of notes and flash cards help for remembering dates.

Really into his work, knows his stuff.  Problem with this class is having an interest just as deep as him.  Expects you to know minor details, i.e: dates, inspirational reasons, very difficult.  Unless you need to, don't take an art history class.

Took this course for general history requirement. Expects everyone in the class to have a background in history and read the four books he assigned us. Did not give good feedback. Would give a poor grade and no reasoning behind it besides a few comments. If youre not a history major & need to fulfil your history requirement, dont take this class.

No tests or HW, but there are four papers, daily group worksheets, and attendance. The papers aren't too bad but she is very specific about what she wants, down to how to indent paragraphs. There is a LOT of reading, and most of it is really boring, so beware. But she is very helpful and willing to explain further, and the lectures are interesting!

You only need the text books for the four unit assignment you have to read. I did not of the nightly readings and was fine. No official final either!!!!!! Shes not a bad lecturer at all and she is definitely passionate about her field.

Took her Maymester class, and it was a pretty simple A. No midterms, or exams which I like since I'm horrible at test taking. Written tests everyday (only covering the material learned that day) are the majority of the grade, but as long as you go to class and pay a little attention you'll be fine.
Worst teacher I've ever had at OSU. Terrible lectures, boring & useless assignments. Makes this class an absolute drag

Takes the class way too seriously for a GEC and is one of the harshest graders I have ever had. Expects you to know things after hearing things once and treats you like a 2nd grader most of the time. Comes off a bit abrasive and doesn't  make the class incredibly interesting.

I agree with other comment. Does take the class way too seriously, no one wants to focus this hard on a stupid GEC class. Most of my major classes are easier!! Assigns a lot of readings for homework and the tests are hard. I would avoid having her.
Grad Student.  Takes class way too seriously, needs to realize this is a GEC course and not everyone cares about history as much as she does.  Strictest grader I have ever come across.  Try to avoid
loved wendy great lectures nice, funny clear and concise "strict"

The topic had so much potential but Wendy managed to make the class painful. She was not a flexible teacher, rude and unclear. We had response papers every week that were graded too hard and didn't help to learn the material too well. Also, the final was pretty hard considering the lack of preparation that was given beforehand.

An awful prof, don't take him. Boring, disorganized, syllabus is wrong and hasn't been updated. So disrespectful to students, I mean, the least he can do is update his syllabus. Always makes mistakes, then acts petty. Very harsh grader, and changes the weight grade at the end of the semester, messing up the grades! Horrific, should be fired.

Professor Tadlock's class wasn't the easiest, but it also wasn't the hardest either. Although the textbook is "required", it was seldom used. His tests are really just long essays that will leave your hands cramping when you're finished. Despite all this, I enjoyed his class, since he knew what he was talking about and had a good sense of humor.

I took his HIST2213 class online and it was okay. There is a TON of reading in this course and be sure to take notes on the readings. I took this class in the summer while working 60 hour work weeks and received an A. If you put in the effort and can get over the crazy amounts of reading/writing, this is a pretty easy class.

Stephen is one of those online professors who takes his job WAY TOO seriously. He makes you read absurd amounts of pages each week only to post his own lectures on Carmen telling you how what you read is incorrect and the books author is wrong. His tests are all long essays which is ridiculous and he provides no feedback. The quizzes are hard too.

This was the most frustrating class I have taken in four years at OSU. Prof Tadlock requires you to read hundreds of pages a week out of a book that he then spends pages on carmen degrading and correcting what he perceives to be errors by the author. He is a tough grader and his section of this class is horrible and exhausting.

I just got my grade back and luckily its a full A. But DO NOT TAKE THIS TA. This is supposed to be an easy A, instead it's 100+ pages of REQUIRED readingsweek, with weekly discussions and quizzes. His lectures are INCOMPREHENSIBLE. They are 4-5 pages of him telling you his opinions on the book in the longest, most pompous and stupid sentences ever

UNORGANIZED! -w/o a syllabus, I would have had no idea which assignments were due when. -syllabus needed updating as it appeared to be due dates from a previous semester/contained many errors. -All assignments were not opened until their due dates (sometimes after) -no communication/announcements outlining the upcoming week -SO MUCH READING

Half a semester online course. Five extremely lengthy textbooks assigned with lectures that are two+ hours long. Quizzes are precise to the exact word to answer the question. Two 3-5 Book Analyses that expects students to compact a 250+ page book into 3-5 pages. Easy discussion posts and two replies , but lengthy. Idk why this man is still a prof.

This was a half semester online course. There are five 250+ page text books assigned, along with 2 hour lectures to watch each week. Quizzes are very detailed to the assigned reading. I am usually an A student, but the quizzes made it difficult to do well. Discussion posts each week are fairly easy, but lengthy! Lots of work for a gen ed class.

I detest this man. He was a TA in my history class and took it upon himself to be the toughest grader I've ever had. Seriously, avoid him at all costs. I am an almost straight-A student, and I couldn't get this guy to give me anything higher than an 85%. His feedback is garbage as well, focusing more on your grammar than the content.

While the lectures and material are very interesting, the readings are crazy! 3 chapters (200 pages) a night!  Daily essay quizzes are very specific so you must take notes  when reading... Very time consuming and must dedicate a lot of time to analyzing the text.

Took his class about the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Very easy to understand and makes sure that people understand the material. Names are important to him and never hesitate to ask him for help if you need clarification. The class was very interesting and if you do the work and put in the effort, youll get an easy A or A-.

I took a class with Prof. Hoffmann about the USSR and never anticipated it would be so interesting. Not only are his lectures extremely straightforward but he adds small anecdotes that I found hilarious. Prof. Hoffmann is the reason I decided to go into the E. Euro/Russian history specialization!

Excellent professor, makes class very interesting. I'm not a fan of history but I still really enjoyed his class. If you listen to what Dr. Hoffmann says, work hard, and participate in class you should do well but don't expect an easy A.

Prof. Hoffman is excellent. After taking numerous online courses, he is by far the easiest professor to communicate with at a distance. Truly cares about his students and has realistic expectations. Also really helped me better understand the study of history and I hope to take him again in the future!

Dr. Hoffmann is a fantastic professor and cares a lot about his students. This course was online; however, he is constantly involved in discussions and providing feedback. I appreciated that he was the most involved professor I have ever had for an online course. Weekly assignments are not bad if you stay on top of them. I loved the course layout.

Prof. Hoffmann seems really shy, but he is also very kind and organized. He really does learn names instantly (it's uncanny), and he's responsive to students. Gives you everything needed for exams and will help with essays, but PARTICIPATE. He grades a bit harshly on participation, and it's 20% of your grade.

I was dreading taking my Senior Seminar for my History degree and I put it off for several semesters. It was worth the wait to take Dr. Hoffmann's SovietStalinist History research seminar.  He is kind, patient, thoughtful, helpful, and brilliant. I would recommend to anyone who has the chance to take a class taught by Dr. Hoffmann.

You have to go to class to do well. Midterm/final are 3 identifications that are marked on his slides (which he does not post online) and one essay question (he gives you 5 to study and then chooses one). One 8-page paper due end of term, plus participation. Super interesting class..highly recommend taking if you have time.
He is a very nice guy. If you need help he will always give it to you.

To be honest, I love history but was not crazy about taking a class on the USSR. Now I am sure glad that I did. This class was so interesting and Prof Hoff is outstanding. He's a meek and mild guy and very nice/caring. He always gave interesting facts on the USSR. The only complaint I have is I think I participated more than I was credited for.
One of the best professors I've ever had. Very clear format for class/exams. He gives you everything you need to get an A. Cannot recommend him enough, I loved his class.

He is extremely knowledgeable and one of the best teachers I have had. He covers a lot of material but because he is well organized and prepares you well for exams, there's no reason why you shouldn't get an A. Tons of (great) readings, though you could get by without reading them. He learns names instantly. Cuban Missile Crisis simulation was fun.

Great class! He is so adorable because he is so nice and very interested in helping students! There was a lot of reading (good ones) for the course, but I actually just read the book reviews instead....Tests are straightforward, the paper is not too bad, and he is a really fair grader. One of my favorite classes and profs at OSU in my 5 years!  :)

Great prof. The class itself was kind of boring, but Dr. Hoffmann knows his stuff, and made the class somewhat interesting. He's a fairly tough grader on papers, but class participation is pretty easy.
great professor, always kept class interesting, clear on what to know for exams.  learned a lot, highly recommend this prof.

Amazing professor. He is incredibly organized and obviously cares about his teaching. He keeps class very interesting and will remember your name immediately (spooky). The class has a lot of reading but not too much work other than that - a midterm, 7-8 Page term paper, and a final. One of OSU's best professors with an interesting class!

Lectures are very well organized, and there is always time for discussion.  He is a very fair grader and lets you know ahead of time what you will need to know.  Not too much work either. Great Class!

I don't really like History, but his lectures were always filled with interesting facts and quirks.  He has an amazing ability to learn students' names, wow.  Very clear on what to learn for the tests and very willing to help students.

Wonderful!  A good lecturer, helpful in discussion and one on one.  Really keeps discussion moving.  Picks interesting books, fair grader.  Overall, a really fine professor- I also like talking to him and taking his courses.
Great teacher! Very diplomatic during discussions. Lectures are very organized and he succinctly points out the significance of events.
No Comments
Course was History of the Soviet Union.  Informative notes, engaging lectures, and the Cuban Missile Crisis simulation was great.  Possibly my favorite prof I've had so far.

Dr. Eaglin's entire curriculum was based off her lectures-- you had to take notes thoroughly to write the papers. The content was rudimentary, but there were a TON of writing and reading assignments. Grading was very, very lenient though. She had a very basic teaching style but did make lectures tolerable and interesting.

The class is informative and easy - papers graded easily and easy discussion. Dr. Eaglin teaches as though she's teaching to freshman in high school. She asks rhetoric questions all the time expecting answers and even took time out of class to discuss what introductory/conclusion sentences and thesis statements are for a 3,000 level course (?????).
She is very considerate and cares about her students. Make sure to do the reading.

Took history of medicine in western society as a GE. Way too much work for a GE class. Lots of homework/projects and tests are super in-depth. Would not recommend unless you're prepared to spent a ton of time,

History of Medicine in Film. While I found this class very interesting, it's one of the hardest GE courses I've taken to date. The assigned readings are extremely long and are easily confused with one another. She is also an extremely tough grader. Don't take this class unless you're ready to put some serious time and effort into it.

History of Medicine in Films. She made it clear that this wasn't going to be an easy class right away, but I wasn't too concerned since it was a GE. This was so hard. She is very tough at grading papers and expects you to think for yourself to come up with your own answers for tests. If you use examples from class don't expect too great of a grade.

I took the History of Western Medicine because I wanted to challenge myself by learning something new. Although the assigned readings were long, I genuinely enjoyed her lectures. The only problem was that the exams became quite difficult once we were expected to memorize over 100 dates and names + info about 30 primary/secondary sources per test.

Dr. Lawrence is an amazing professor and mentor. If you have the opportunity to take History 2800H with her, she is incredibly helpful. Thanks to her, I have developed my writing to be more concise, and I have a good idea for my Honors thesis. Find your passion and develop it for your final project, and you'll do well!

Professor hempson turned what could have been an interesting subject into a very dry, boring class. I also found him to be unreasonable in terms of his quizzes and condescending when contacting the class. Perhaps if it were not an online class he would be better, but I would certainly not recommend this class because of him.
Condescending, rude, serious lack of professionalism. Had to retake the class with a different professor and scored in the high B's. He is not worth the time or money.

The reading load was heavy. (I am not afraid of hard work but it is far too much reading for a class) His quizzes get progressively harder so be prepared. The last one was a lot of questions and many were pointless in my opinion. There are better classes at OSU about diplomacy than this.

Hempson is a very knowledgable instructor, and I was inspired by his teachings.  However, the reading load was a bit much with all my other classes, but overall I generally enjoyed this class - and he did tell us it was a reading intensive course on day one.

I strongly advise you to NOT take this class with Dr. Hempson. The workload is absurd. His emails concerning class business are rude and disheartening. Enrolling in this class was the biggest mistake. If you can, steer clear and take this class in person with a different professor.

Dr. Hempson puts a lot of emphasis on making sure that students make connections from UN to UN case, linking events in history to what's happening now in the world, and that is the most important part of teaching, being able to connect the topics in class to the current world.
Dr. Hempson is a very tough teacher, but he is very knowledgeable in the subject matter. I have taken all his classes and would take more if I could.

Not clear on what he is going to quiz on before he opens the quiz. Work load is RIDICULOUS as if he expects us to only be taking his class. Do not recommend. I really wanted to take this class and the material really is interesting it's just that the way the class is structured is far too stressful.
Do not recommend. The amount of work assigned is unreasonable when combined with a full class load. Stay away.

Through the readings & the lectures he gave, Prof. Hempson really made this class interesting & stimulating.  He managed to address any issue students encountered and was always shedding an unseen or uncommon light on events.  Thus triggering genuine interest in his students in his class.  This class was one of my favorite at OSU for these reasons.
Hardest Professor I have encountered, also the best.

Dr. Hempson is one of the most excellent professors I've had at The Ohio State University.  He challenges his students like few others and expects high quality work, as well as challenges to think through their ideas very thoroughly.

Never been challenged so much, but loved evey minute of it.  I learned so much from his classes. He helped me become a better writer, a more critical thinker, and overall to strive more for excellence in all my work.  I loved all his lectures and he definitely helped me to raise the bar of standards in all that I do. The group project was esp. fun.
One of the toughest, yet perhaps most excellent, professors I've ever had.

I took this class last fall.  It was a very intellectual challenging class. His standard is very straightforward and fair.  He is alo wlling to help students at the office hours.  I learned a lot from the class and from his office hours. I enjoyed the class much.

The variation of workload is a little annoying and some would call the grading on papers as borderline sadistic, but I find it fair. Overall however, the class was excellent and it was filled with information that made other classes seem comparably shallow.
Dr. Hempson is extremely knowledgeable and I greatly enjoyed this class!  He expects a lot from his students, but nothing unreasonable.

He assigns a lot of readings and can be categorized as a tough grader but that is in no way a bad assessment of his teaching ability. It was a tough class but i enjoyed it and would highly recommend this class for any one who is interested in this topic.

This is the second time I have taken a class with Dr. Hempson. I have enjoyed both of my classes with him, but I was pleased that his teaching style has changed.  The course remains a rigorous, thought provoking introduction to the issues global leaders are currently dealing with and the material is interesting.

i was very interested in the subject matter going into this class but it turned out to be a real pain. There was a ridiculous amount of reading for his quizzes that were only 5-10 questions long. It is nearly impossible to finish the reading with other classes. It is almost like he is clueless to the fact students have other classes to go to.

Dr Hempson is the best professor I have had at OSU. He is a tough grader but if you came to college expecting to sail through I'm sure you had a difficult time in his class and posted bad reviews. Go to class and take detailed notes. Spend time on the paper. Do the readings. You will do well if you put in effort.
This is one of the best professors that I have had in my 12 years of college.  He is hard, but very helpful.  Take his classes!!!!  BCJC

He is a great teacher and takes a lot of time to make his lectures and supplemental powerpoints interesting. You should read the paper guidelines carefully and have someone check your paper; he does expect a lot from his students' papers. I also found him to be very approachable and helpful in office hours. Overall, great prof!

He really knows his stuff in regards to the subject. His paper grading is very severe, borderline sadistic but he won't slap an F on there.I had a court stenographer proof my papers and I still didn't do any better than an 80. Don't mistake his attitude for rudeness. He's just a very serious guy.

Dr. Hempson is thorough in his grading,but brutally honest.He is by far one of the best I've had here at OSU.However,he expects the best from you.A very classy, well-bred man,he can be severe on those who half-ass assignments.If you pay attention, you will learn more in this class than any others you will take.You will not find a better instructor.

Hempson will ALWAYS find something wrong with your work. He expects perfection and professionalism - but gives no evidence of it himself in his grading. His grading comments are degrading, base, and completely lacking in peer-to-peer professionalism. I seriously doubt he edits his colleagues the way he does his students. Avoid if possible.

I had professor Hempson for both 550 and for 551. He is hands down one of the most knowledgeable professors  I have ever had, and I encourage anyone majoring in IS to take his classes. I enjoyed 551 better than 550 because we did projects which focused on UN cases, and they opened everyone's eyes. Paper assignments=tests. 1 of the best at OSU!

If you want to actually learn from an extremely knowledgeable person, take his class. If you want to skate by, never ever take a class with him. He is a tough grader and is extremely hard on your writing. Dr. Hempson expects you to grasp the material at a level in which you can speak intelligently about it. That is a fair assessment.
really awful.

Professor and class are a little challenging. You get out of the class what you put in. If you attend class, do the readings, and most importantly, PROOFREAD your papers, you will do well. He is helpful when approached. He is perhaps a bit excessive on his expectations for professional courtesy.

Couldn't disagree more with negative comments.  Very down to earth, very clear, very willing to help. If you don't review your papers before turning them in, you will not do well in this class (you will also not do well in college).  Very interesting lecturer.  Would never have thought to call him pompous, but he does obviously love the material

Run if you have either of his classes! I've taken both, thought I'd give him a 2nd chance, and was reminded of his imcompetancy and disrespectful behavior. Even if you were a english major you'd probably never receive an A on any of the 4 papers you must write. Pompous and unhelpful. I'm an A paper writer who gets avg of C's. Flee this rude prof!
Absolutetely amazing! He's classes are extremely challenging and intellectually stimulating. On top of that he is gorgeous :)

This professor expects you read large amounts of boring text for the most part. Even if you are interested in the subject, the class is very dry at times and lectures seem like they take forever. He only assigned four papers which is good or bad depending on your writing skills (content and grammar). Nice guy though.

This professor is so tough. The professor is really awful and his lectures are so tedious. You literally have to read 100 pages before each class. As for the papers he grades like a 500 level English professor. He takes off for every incorrect comma. After 3 mistakes he'll stop reading your paper and basically you're screwed. DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS!

I took him for Int'l 550. He is the professor from hell, because he can't teach. It feels like his always giving a speech and trying to prove to us just how smart he is. Also, his very critical when it comes to grading papers and a lot of readings. I basically hated his class and not because its hard, but because his not good at teaching.

Dr. Hempson is incredibly knowledgeable about his subject and likes to challenge students on it. Immense amount of reading was assigned but if you keep up, it will be a lot easier to sit through his lectures because he summarizes everything from the books. If you are interested to learn about the UN missions, then you will definitely like this clas

I took his classes, Int.Stds. 551 and 550, this quarter.  His lectures are interesting and relevant, and eventually a little bit of his personality came through.  He does grade the TONS of writing assignments he assigns critically, but he always gives advice on how to improve.  His class was intellectually challenging and he was helpful in office h

This SOB was one helluva professor!  He was jazzed about his topic, related the topics to our various majors/interests and was always prepared with a detailed answer to questions.  The last moron to review him must have forgotten why he decided to go to college - drop out if you don't want to put in the effort!  Dr. Hempson is the ideal prof!

this guy sucks. yes his tests are moderately easy, minus the essay part. his two page papers are unfairly graded, one of those "i don't have an english degree, but i will take**** tons of points off for incorrect english" - he doesn't respect students opinions that much either - oh well. i got a C for no effort.

A lot of people were falling asleep, but I thought it was interesting and relavent. Easily the best class I took at OSU so far. He is a harsh grader on papers, but he gives you enough feedback to plan for it in later writings. I will agree that he appears moderately pretentious, but it isn't the case.

He comes across as moderately pretentious but is surprisingly helpful when approached. He challenges you to turn in quality work, and at least he's attractive to look at while he lectures ~_-  Overall, one of the better GEC profs I've taken.
He give good, clear notes.  Very nice also.  Pretty easy.
he actually made class interesting. I hated 11 so much i was dreading 112.. but it was cool.

This guy is kinda a hardass, but he is very willing to help if you put a reasonably expected amount of work into his class.  Even with all the stuff he made us know about East Europe I actually liked the class and learned alot.  You don't have to like the guy, right?  He just has to be good at teaching and he is (but he is a hardass).
He tends to be pretty a pretty cool prof.  He may be quick on going over notes but he will always go back and will answer any question.  Test are a bit tough but a good class overall.
No Comments

Professor Gregory is a really nice man, however his class was extremely unorganized. It was difficult to get a hold of him if I had any questions regarding the material, and assignments were not graded in a timely manner. The readings assigned every week were a little excessive, but overall the assignments were fairly easy.

Very unclear about assignments and when they were due. Would take things down and put them up after half the class did them. No direction whatsoever. I emailed both him and all of his TA's multiple times for answers regarding many things I couldn't find in the syllabus. I had to drop the class because nothing made sense.

Worst class I've ever taken at OSU by far. Never take an online class with him. So disorganized and literally asked me to help him figure out how to use Carmen. Also, no class syllabus so good luck with that. Grades discussion posts unnecessarily hard. Save yourself the headache and do not take his classes. AVOID AVOID AVOID!

Class was very disorganized. Put a C in for my final grade instead of an A, and it still hasnt changed. You can pick 3 assignments to do out of 3 papers and a midterm and final exam. Papers and tests were graded fairly, just very late. I didnt learn a single thing. Not a difficult A, but a frustrating class to take due to disorganization.

Not an easy class. Very disorganized, we received a syllabus revision three times throughout the semester because we were given incorrect due dates. 60% of the class was split between 3 essays, which I did not receive grades for until the semester ended. Overall the class is just disorganized and graded very tough, would not recommend.

Please do not take any of his online courses, I'm not even sure he knew he was teaching the course. Most of his assignments were not posted at the right times, closed at the wrong times, or didn't exist. The semester is 3 days from over, and I have 3/20 assignments graded. He has not responded to a single email I've sent him. Not worth the hassle.

Prof. Tim was very unorganized, to say the least. I strongly recommend you choose another instructor. I did take this as a GE. I am a second-year student and have had a 4.0 up until this course. I figured it would be fine as long as I did the work. It is okay, but Prof. Tim is not skilled in putting grades into Carmen or using it correctly. Avoid.

To start, this class (online version) is definitely an easy A as long as you do the work. However, Timothy Gregory is awful. He is incredibly disorganized, will never respond to emails, and constantly contradicts the syllabus. All in all, if you need an easy history GE, take this class. But, prepare to be confused and to email your TA a lot.

Do. Not. Take. Him. He never responds to e-mails. It took me THREE WEEKS AND FIVE EMAILS for him to fix a quiz that he entered wrong for me. Hours and hours of reading pointless material and the quiz questions literally have nothing to do with the class. Never in my life have I had a more frustrating class/professor.

Terrible teacher. Midterm and final are both written, for the final he expects 2 full length essays over unspecific overreaching concepts that no one would ever have picked up on before the question was given. you have the option to write papers instead of exams. write the papers. write the papers. save yourself, write the papers. rip my gpa

This class was awful. Gregory was awful. I'm really bothered by the # of posts from  people who were in different semesters and courses he has taught all saying the same thing. The fact he has in multiple classes not posted a syllabus in a timely manner or been response to students is absurd. Do NOT take a course with professor Gregory, seriously.

Dr. Gregory taught my online classical archaeology class, and he was one of the worst professors I have ever had. He is horribly disorganized and unclear with assignments. For the midterm, he had 4 different dates listed for when the exam was available. Easily one of the worst professors I have ever had. I would give him0/5 if I could.

I haven't even finished that class but I can say it's the worst class I've taken at ohio state. I'm a double humanities major and I can handle the readings. He gives you every detail about every event in the byzantine empire and even as a history major, its too much to keep up with. I'm so lost in this class id drop it if I could. save yourselves.

Isn't aware he's teaching gen ed history. He wants lengthy essays, constant discussions about the book (his own book btw), and offers no study guides for exams. Here is a copied quote he gave us before the final-"By far the best way to do well in the exam is to do all the readings and look at ALL the material in the course before you take the exam"

Gregory was totally out of touch with the students. Was impossible to contact, never got a email response, even after multiple attempts. Assigns way too much reading and assignments - its not humanly possible to complete. Not to mention the complete lack of organization in the course - WE DIDN'T EVEN GET AN ACCURATE SYLLABUS UNTIL OCTOBER!

Gregory is just completely out of touch with modern schooling. He still believes that making you read an entire book in a week is good idea. He really expects a lot out of you and to be fully knowledgable in the book that he wrote. The worst thing is that he doesn't really test about the actual facts, you are tested on his interpretation of it.
I loved this class. Was definitely and Easy A. Weekly discussion and quizzes with two papers or a midterm and a finals. I decided to do the papers because you get more time. Overall an easy A.

Tried to contact him multiple times for clarification and never heard back. He was gone the first half of the semester and by the time he was back was still unable to get a hold of him. Class was a nightmare and made for a bad learning experience. Pretty bad when you cant even get a single reply the entire semester.

There was just TOO MUCH reading and too many assignments. You can choose between taking exams (which are ridiculous questions) or a number of 7-page papers. My TA graded too hard, i dont know if this was a reflect of Gregory but it made this supposedly-easy GE a nightmare and a GPA downer. Too much content to memorize.

Online class. You have to post a weekly discussion and reply. Lots of reading from the book as well as primary sources. You have the option to take exams or write papers. The ta's grade incredibly hard on the tests and papers. The tests are essay and short answr and I got 80s on them and 70s on papers. His extra credit saves you tho.

Worst and hardest class I have taken at OSU. Why bother  studying for test when questions are out of left field.  Hard grader essays and doesn't give any feedback on how to improve.  Most time and energy I have every put into a class and literally got a D.  Don't waste your time here.

Great professor. Really chill class. Super easy if you do the work. A little time consuming but you don't usually have to actually read to pass quizzes. Did one project and one midterm, both were pretty easy. Don't have to take test if you prefer projects.

Do NOT take a class with Dr. Gregory. His class is disorganized, his syllabus is contradictory (ALL THE DATES ARE WRONG), quizzes have many mistakes, and from my experience, he was rude when I tried to contact him about a quiz error. The only nice aspect was that this class was online.

Professor Gregory did a good job of summarizing ancient history. Attending class is neither mandatory not really necessary (301 is online class, 301H has lectures)but worthwhile since he is good lecturer and has amusing discussions. Our section met 2/3 of scheduled days, began late, and ended early.

Online class, easy A if you put in the work (which isn't much). Easy weekly quizzes take 10 mins and can be retaken until you get 100%. Can do short (1-2 pg) papers instead of midterm/final. Definitely take for a GEC to free up your schedule

Not a bad class. Like others have said you get to pick your own grade, however discussion is mandatory (and tedious). A lot of reading for a GEC, but you can get by without doing all of it. Definitely an A if you are willing to work a bit.

Online Class.  The class is what you make of it.  You get to choose the assignements that you want to complete except for the mandatory discussion.  This and the schedule is fantastic for people who are very busy who have specific learning styles.  Stay on top of the reading and make sure you understand what is expected of you!

Get to pick your own grade. retake quizzes until you pass. the only annoying part was the amount of reading was a bit ridiculous for a 100 level class. for people that dont like history its okay, but really dry reading. im glad its over, the prof is okay, but the class was huge, rules can be confusing at times. okay for online though.

Prof Gregory does an excellent job with this online class. I read another review saying that it was hard for an undergrad class but clearly that person was from a comunity college or something. The class is graded so that you pick what you do for your grade (I did quizzes, discussions, and 2 papers so no midterm or final!) take the class. easy GEC
Fair amount of reading. Quizes are 10 multiple choice questions and exams are pretty easy. Highly recommend.
Teaches mainly online classes. You don't have to go onto Carmen and participate daily, but it is part of your grade to some degree a few days per week.
Very easy online course. He is a fair teacher and gives you multiple options to accumulate a 100%. The only mandatory thing was discussions which were fun.

306d, 505.01d, and 505.02d. Don't know why ppl say this is a hard prof. You earn 100% of your grade. You choose what makes up your grade, unlimited chances to take quizzes and open book exams. Classes were the most interesting and easiest courses I've taken. I'm getting a minor in hist with a +3.8 GPA because 3 of my 4 courses with with Dr Gregory.
Very helpful. This was an online class. As long as you keep up it's a very easy A.

Professor Geregory was very helpful! He made his class fun and interesting. Going into this class, I thought it was just going to be another boring History class, but the way that he chose to teach it to us really helped me to get into the material! Great professor!

Online class is easy.  Just get on there every day, keep up with the posts, and make a few decent posts of your own and you'll be fine.  Gives you several options of grades among papers, quizzes, and tests.

TEG's online courses are great.  Well-organized and complete with weekly video lectures, they feel almost like a traditional class. He requires multiple weekly (intelligent) discussion posts, which may discourage some, but either he or the TA's respond to nearly every message posted, an amazing enough feat in itself. You earn the grade you get.

TEG is an interesting guy.  111D was way too hard for a freshman level class, luckily I had already taken several 500 level classes before that.  the upper level history classes he teaches online are definitely classes you should take.  Work is relatively easy, he's helpful, and you have lots of choices to make your grade.  Definitely recommend.
Great in all areas.

He makes his online courses straight forward and clear. U always know what is expected. He lets u pick what u want to use to make up your grade - so u may never take an exam. U have to post 4 times a week, but these posts are the size of this comment. he lets u take the quizes as many times as you want, and gives you 5 weeks to take them.

Professor Gregory's classes aren't tough if you keep up with the work.  I don't know where everyone is getting that it's "hard work".  He's quick to respond, helpful, and gives you a chance to get an A.  You should have no problem getting an A in his online course.
TEG is great! His classes require some amount of work, but very worth it. He's a sweet and brilliant man and his classes are some of the most engaging I've had at OSU.

Don't take this as a GEC online because it takes too much time and effort.  You're expected to read atleast a chapter a week and post in a disucssion forum at least 4 times a week for a C.  They grade your posts based on length and quality, so its not easy to BS something.

I think we are all seeing the pattern here: not good for distance courses (remember, the TA he uses can effect your experience greatly). But don't write him off, he's a wonderful man. I have dealt with him for advising also. Face-to-face is better

Took an online class from him, it was a terrible experience.  You must check the website constantly or be prepared to start missing points.  I will never take a class from him again, and I'm a History major with a 3.8 GPA
i took his online course which was tough as balls, there was work 7 days a week and you had to constantly check the website for him to even think about giving you an a. he seems kinda goofy.
Online class was a lot harder than you would think.  A riduclous amount of work for a GEC.  Hated the class!!!
Extremely through.
Best History Prof I ever had - inspirational at times and I'm not even a History Major.  Spent a summer in Greece with a study tour he led and can't imagine a better guide.
He was an excellent professor.  We even talked him into having a pizza party.  I haven't had a pizza party since high school.
Very good professor, very clear and interesting to listen to, class was sometimes boring (but it is history); very cool guy

I went into an online Medieval History class not expecting much and was blown away by how much I genuinely enjoyed the class. Professor Shimoda made an engaging, interesting, and challenging (without being ridiculously hard) class experience that I thoroughly appreciated. He was a fantastic professor and I highly recommend this class!

Dr. Shimodas Medieval class was great. Every week, we listened to a lecture and read several documents from the time period. Then, we had a short quiz (very easy if you read the documents!) and a Discussion Board where we asked/answered questions about the documents. He answers e-mails quickly & gives good feedback. Highly recommended!
Kyle Shimoda is a great professor when it comes to Medieval History.. he gave a lot of opportunities for extra credit and even rounded my 91 up to an A.

Dr. Shimoda is a great and fair professor. We had 2 lectures a week, had to read primary source documents, and then had to write discussion posts off of the primary sources. It is a very interesting and easy class as long as you are willing to do the readings and work.

Professor Shimoda did a great job of making an online class super accessible and fair to everyone that is in it. Workload was super fair. Some of the sources you have to read every week are a little lengthy, but the content is really interesting so they become easy reads. Kyle is a super nice and cool guy who really cares about all of his students.

Class was pretty easy, weekly video lecture and 50pgs per week to read. 2 discussion posts out of 5 prompts ddue every Sunday as well as a 5question quiz that can be taken a second time but with only 1 question the same. Thought I failed the midterm but got an A haven't done the final yet but I have an A so far.

Dr. Shimoda is clearly knowledgeable in what he teaches, however he treats this 1000 level course like a 4000 or 5000 level course. I understand that he is a recent doctorate recipient, which is great, but not everyone is at that level. In addition, the TA I have been assigned to is incredibly disrespectful and will not offer assistance when needed

Mr. Shimoda did not clarify any work that needed to be done for this class. He is not willing to help the student and when asked to meet he is never willing. He forgot to post our weekly quiz numerous times. If you are expecting what says is a GE this is NOT the course to take. Kyle treats this as a 4000 level course and is a horrible teacher!!!

super nice guy. wants you to work hard for your grade and learn a lot in the class but makes accommodations if you need them. lectures are fast and can be confusing but since its online its easy to slow them down or rewind them.

Professor Harris's online lectures were slow and sound like he was reading off of a script. He grades extremely harshly for how unclear his grading scheme is. Wouldn't recommend him as a professor but if you have to take him you aren't necessarily screwed. Just make sure to ask exactly what he's looking for because he will not make it clear to you.

Okay, I would not call this class fun. It is a lot of reading and writing, but it is incredibly interesting. An A is easy if you do the work or ask Professor Harris for help. He is extremely willing to help out on anything within the class. The lessons you learn in this class are lessons I think should be mandatory for everyone.

James led my recitations and I really enjoyed his class. It was all discussion based, so as long as you read the required readings, the class was enjoyable. James also graded my papers and I felt like he graded pretty fair. Tougher than I would have hoped for, but he graded the midterm easy and the final VERY easy. Great teacher and good guy! 10/10

This was the easiest A I've ever made! Going into the class I wasn't sure of the subject matter as I wasn't knowledgeable in Islamic History, but Sanja is great at her job and presents the material in an easy to digest manner. I definitely recommend taking her class.
She is very caring and approachable. She has a real subtle humor which comes through in her online lectures. I really liked her and I'd take her class again.
Don't take her class online if you are a full-time student she was doing way too much

I took this class as a humanities class. It looks like everyone rated this well. She has graders that do everything for her. THEY GRADE SO HARD! For you discussion posts you are only suppose to write 250 words, then they give you a 50% for not going into detail. How do you go into detail with 250 works

Sanja is an amazing teacher. I took her class online and if you do the discussions, listen to the lectures, and read the readings you'll do fine. The final paper is with 40% percent of your grade but she helps you along the way.

By far the most entertaining and interesting instructor I've had. Many opportunities to do well: daily responses, quizzes, papers, particip., but the work must be done to succeed. She uses her wit and humor to engage the class, and you wont want to skip--wouldn't want to miss the surprise GIF of the day. Extremely knowledgeable, and very helpful.
She is a great teacher, lots of reading but good discussions. She's funny, easy to listen to, and I definitely developed a little crush on her.

Sanja is an amazing professor. Read an article before class, write for five minutes about the reading, sit through a 20 minute lecture, have a class discussion and repeat. She is clear in what she teaches and what she wants. She is hilarious, professional, helpful and not going to lie, you will have a friend crush on her by the end of the semester.

Best professor ive ever take in my life. Inspirational and interesting lectures. Im not a history major but i definitely became a lot more interested in history afterwards. Very caring as well. Take her if you can

Loved her, her TA was a little tough on grading but in the end it was okay. Pretty easy to do well in the class as long as you showed up and took notes. She was an amazing professor and I will definitely take her again, one of my favorite history classes I have ever taken here!

She is really great and very interesting lectures, I really loved all the material in the class and really felt like I understood everything, but both her and her TA are stupid hard graders and it is very discouraging.

Lecture is long and monotonous. Computers not allowed, so you have to hand write notes. She'll pass out "vocab sheets" at the beginning of lecture, but ends up skipping most of the terms on there. Readings are long and boring, but necessary for quizzes/exams. Papers are graded like it's an English class. Don't take if you don't have to.

Prof. Beach is a decent professor. She tells stories to make her concepts flow naturally and understandable. Her power points are just pictures so make sure you are paying attention in class. Also, get ready to go work because she this class requires a lot of readings and papers. She is a tough grader.
This is a very great class to take for your history GE! she is so nice and cares abotu her student success. Spent most of the semester on the vikings. Moderate amount of work. would recommend

Great class with an awesome prof! You can definitely tell she cares about the material and gets really excited in class... Was taking this as a GEC as a science major not expecting much, but was surprised by how engaging it is. Would def recommend!

Worst experience with a GE professor. Way too much reading, expects way too much from her students (who clearly aren't history majors, nor really care about the material).Doesn't write anything on her powerpoints, speaks for the whole class period. Doesn't stay focused on one topic, very scattered brain. Unable to work technology. AVOID AVOID AVOID

I really enjoyed her class on Medieval Christianity. It really educated both the students I knew who had a Catholic background and those who had a Protestant background. She also helped to relate the "dark ages" with society now, and seeing that human history is very much the same then as it is now.

Awesome teacher. She is extremely helpful (go to her office hours!) and wants to make sure everyone does well. Definitely works with you not against you, and makes class enjoyable. I recommend taking her classes to anyone

Beach is awesome. She lays out what is expected from you in the class. She is also very flexible. Attend her office hours so she can get to know you better. She loves questions in class and class participation!

took him at Wright state for a greek and roman history class. What a shame. this man is absolutely brilliant and made me care and interested in listening to his lectures. He missed over half of our classes and never graded anything. ended up just giving everyone an A. He was canned from Wright state which he didn't care because he was hired at osu
Never posted anything on time

Greg is a great guy. He truly cares about each of his students. There were many classes that were cancelled but there was usually a valid reason. To be honest, not having class was a relief sometimes because it was so early in the morning. If you hate humor, don't take this class. He is a great guy with even better stories. Most of the class is lec

Greg is the funniest professor I have ever had. He likes to engage with the class and tell funny stories. This class was based on attendance and a lengthy final paper, but you are almost guaranteed to get an A on it as long as you talk it over with Greg at least once before you turn the paper in.

This class was incredible. Dr. Pellam is one of those few teachers who makes his students want to go above and beyond. After a few weeks, the class is no longer about your grade; it's about you and what you can learn and share with your classmates. I spent 20+ hours on a paper that I was GUARANTEED an A on. Think about that. Now take this class.

This guy is awesome! The best stories of any professor you'll ever have. Hear about the Romans taking military action based on their chickens, accidentally falling asleep in front of an elementary school, and many more! literally just show up and relax, you'll get an A. Books not needed, he is extremely clear on how to get a perfect score.

lectures twice a week were very interesting. no need to participate, just take it all in and write down everything he talks about. the 3 graded papers can be written purely from notes taken in class with a little effort. he tells funny stories and is genuinely interested in hearing what students have to say. will take any class with him
Hillarious, entertaining, and brilliant. Now at Capital University and Wright State. OSU lost the best GTA they ever had!
Greg Pellam is the man

Funny guy. Great story teller. Sometimes rude, though. Participation counts for a lot of points. So, if you don't talk in class usually -- avoid this section. No exams. Just papers. Not too much reading, but some.

Greg's a great teacher. He's quite a story teller, which is incredibly important for a history teacher. His jokes and personal stories are hilarious, and he even makes history interesting. But beware, if you can't handle crude jokes or unconventional behavior, this may not be the teacher for you.
He was super helpful and a lot of fun in class. Go out of your way to get in his section. It will be worth it!
Entertaining, informative, and above all else, easy on the eyes ;-)

Pretty easy prof who knows his ancients but quite on the vulgar side which I feel is unprofessional.  He might grow up one day but until then, you'll be stuck learning about Caesar and his 7 ferrets, all of which are named for his favorite people in history.

Best teacher in the world!! He is so funny and you will still learn so much from him. He has the best stories you wont go a single class with out laughing. Still have to do some work but its a very east A

Mr. Pellam's class was the most amazing experiance that I ever had in the classroom. I would wake up in the morning just waiting for his class. His beard hides his majesty and and his amazing mind. I would sit in his class and daydream of the achient world; he spun his tale so well that is was like you were there.

Let me just say that if he is your TA be ready for a journy and a fork in the road for his personality is split. He wants to help you and will make you think for your self. But his attitude is disrespectful and he is a smart ***. He tries to make the class fun but his attitude kills his help. If your reading this pallum i didn't make the deans cuz

Mr. Pellam's knowledge of the subject, generally accepted and new and provocotive, relative languages both ancient and modern, archaeology, evolution of man and societies, theologies all come together to create the best possible circumstances for actual students. All of his talent, skill and knowledge seem balanced by a genuine humility. Socratic.
The dude's just too cool!
No Comments
good guy
Mr. Pellam is a smarty-pants type. "Ooh, ooh, I speak Latin, aren't I spectacular?" Plus, he won't shut up about his softball team!

Lecture heavy with 2 hrs video lectures per week, no ppts. lots of discussion posts every week, based on lengthy readings (multiple pages). Emails back couple days after you email her, Not very accessible. Lots and lots of reading and work for a 3 credit hr class. Lectures are boring and monotonous. Worst online class!

Half semester courses with too many readings and discussion postings. Tough grader on papers which occupied half of the grade. Funny course to learn more about America history but worst experience to finish dues one after another. It will take at least 6 hours a week to achieve a good grade.

Took 2001 online. Tons of discussion posts from readings making up the majority of your grade, BS'd my way through a few just googling the history and still got full credit. Quiz's are open book and based off her youtube lectures. Put the playback speed on 2.0, turn on captions, and its a cakewalk. Easy class, just submit papers on time or its -10%

Online class, but requires heavy amount of reading to participate in discussions. you'll be spending about 4 hrs just reading for her class, and about 2 hours per week just watching her lectures, doesnt sound bad, but it is. Her lectures are the most boring videos too, she has a monotonous voice and terrible at lecturing. lots of work, but doable.
She is very smart a good at what she does. She is very passionate about her classes, but it is a ton of work, absolutely too much work.

Prof Marino was probably the best professor I've had in college. She is so caring and helpful, and will work with you to improve your writing and research. Showing up and participating is necessary. She gives really good feedback on papers. An amazing professor and person!

Dr. Marino is a great professor & compassionate person. She made a point to learn all her students names & meet with everyone during office hours to get to know them at the beginning of the semester. A LOT of reading and 4 papers in total. You definitely have to work for it to get a good grade but the class is interesting and you learn a lot.

Dr. Marino was one of my favorite professors I've had in college. She was so helpful with every aspect of the class, and very understanding that students have lives outside of classes that sometimes affect their schooling. I wouldnt hesitate to take any of her other classes.

Professor Marino is so knowledgeable about the subject she teaches. It is a bit of work, but if you enjoy the subject it is easy to enjoy what you're doing. She is very attentive to each student's needs, and even made it a point to learn everyone's names even though we had 50+ students.. Very kind and caring. Would recommend.

It should be prefaced this is an environmental history class, we did not talk much on the political/national side as much as we did about flood drainage, dams, soil, etc. He does not care to get to know the students, and only grades on two papers, a midterm, and a final that is worth 35% of your final grade. Overall, his lectures are dry & boring.

He is very knowledgable and kind, however, his class can be a bit unorganized. Sometimes it is difficult to understand what timeline he is describing, which clan, etc. The papers are interesting, and readings as well. You NEED the textbook and it will help you understand the material better.

Hes a nice guy and really knows his stuff, although some things can be a bit unclear or unorganized. If you do need help, he will work with you and encourages that students approach him with problems.

Really tough grader, but isn't clear about what he wants. Thinks he's teaching a writing class and will mark you down for correct information presented in an essay style he doesn't like. If you take the class, ask for a lot of clarity on instructions even if you think there wasn't anything ambiguous. Really read that textbook. Wouldnt recommend.

Professor Brown is a standoffish and demanding man. He has very specific criteria of how papersclass discussions should be conducted, but does not communicate these fully enough to students. I did not enjoy the atmosphere of lectures and found his grading expectations to be disproportionately high considering the info presented.

Worst class I've taken. Reading assigned by week, he'll often get aheadbehind and be furious if you're not ready for discussion when he is, it's hit and miss whether he'll tell you what he wants read when. 12-14 pages of essays due on finals week, with another due only 2 weeks before, really? Good lectures, but not worth the aggravation, avoid.

one of the most brilliant professors I've had the pleasure to study under. His lectures are long but interesting, so long as you are academically minded and are interested in Japan. He offers a lot of good information on study abroad programs, and offers GREAT recommendations for self research! GREAT if you're a history student. do not take if lazy

I actually like his class. I didn't like that the powerpoint slides didn't have most of the info that he discussed thoroughly in class about. But, his papers were straight to the point and he gave a variety of ways on how u can write a particular paper. Overall it was an okay class. just remember to use PRIMARY SOURCES ONLY ON THE PAPERS!!!

Most test are online, using  lockdown browser but can print off the study sheets and have them in front of you. Essays have to cite things from readings but prompts don't cover things from the readings. Recitation was pointless, everything discussed there had been discussed in lecture. Textbook was never used, readings were all online. Very boring.
Talks about random things. Has like nothing written on the powerpoint slides so why even have them.

You will not feel released when you realized that you still had to finish another three final essays about 12 page long in total after you just turned your second paper in one week ago. Lecture did not attract attention from the rest of the class. The harshest grader I've never been experienced.

This class almost killed me.  It was way too much work; eight-page papers and tons of reading.  The people who were majoring in Japanese seemed to love the class, but I (a History major) had trouble following his lectures. However, he is the most helpful professor I have ever had.  If you ask for help, he gives copious amounts.
398 a required but useless class made worse by this guy. Professor assigned his friend's book as the text and was extremely boring.

Lectures were confusing, and often not clear. The material was not presented in an order that was easily understood. Way too many papers to write and things to read for an entry level history class. I had a lot of trouble staying awake for this one. Thankfully my TA was very helpful, and the only reason I passed this class.
HE SUCKS
Worst mistake of my collegiate career. Assumes we know a large amount of Japanese history. Very little explanation and tons of work.

I took Japanese History from him for my pre-1750 non-western requirement, and it was one of the bigger mistakes I could've made in terms of classes to take. Prof. Brown has taught way too many Japanese majors in this class, and assumes that everyone already has a large base knowledge of Japanese history. Too much work with too little explanation.
No Comments
No Comments
Crap load of work for a 100 series history class.  Lots of readings required often.  Decides to space the papers all within a week of each other in the middle of the quarter.

Prof. Flores deeply cares about her class and the topics she teaches. I can tell there is a ton of passion and history behind her lectures. She can be stern with her students but honestly that is a good thing... she does not go un-respected. If you have a passion for history, she may be the prof. for you. Work hard, and it will pay off.

The readings each consume a considerable amount of time. She is a REALLY tough paper/extended response grader, she is almost like an English prof at times it seemed. Shes outspoken about her political views and can sometimes come off as rude. However, its not completely awful as her tests are open note and the material is kinda easy. Participate
Interesting lectures, informative and fabulous reading materials.

This was a great summer course. It had about 2 lectures each week, about an hour long each, but you can easily take the weekly quizzes without watching them. The discussion posts only required a decent amount of effort because you needed to complete the weekly readings to answer the discussion posts. Only 2 papers for the class but he grades fair.

One of the best professors I have had at OSU. I took his History3216 class and it was amazing. He's a very engaging lecturer and a lenient grader. Quizzes and assignments were all very easy. His courses are worth taking without a doubt.
Super interesting class! Dr. Vanderpuy was great and helpful. There is a lot of reading though, many passages from different books (can be found online in pdf form of for a few dollars used).

Professor Vanderpuy is pretty average. I basically never saw the man because the class was asynchronous, but I can't hold that against him. Essays had really varied grading (although some were also graded by a TA), and generally rewarded 8th grade writing style over college writing. However, biweekly quizzes were a good grade boost.

Lectures are long with a lot of tangents/rambling. Material is pretty straight forward so as long as you take notes and pay attention to the lectures, you'll be fine. There are only a handful of assignments, discussions/quizzes/exams. I took it second session and I think the pace is definitely manageable.

Overall, Peter Vanderpuy is a good professor. The class structured around watching approximately 3 lectures videos a week (each at least an hour) with a easy 15 question quiz. There is 1 midterm, 1 paper and a final. Get ready to take lots of notes and write deep analysis papers for the paper midterm and final. Responds to emails quickly.

I took this as an 8-week session course, fully asynchronous online. His lectures were pre-recorded, but he still sent out emails and announcements often. The slides in the lectures were hard to follow, but if you listen to what he is saying and take notes from that, the textbook wasn't really needed. 2 discussion posts and an easy quiz each week.

Seemed really nice. Lectures were all prerecorded. Each week there were a few lecture videos, discussion posts, and a good bit of reading. There's about 6 pretty easy quizzes throughout the semester and you get two attempts for all of them. He also gives you potential midterm and final questions ahead of time. Grades essays generously.

Having taken this class, I thought it was a very easy and well organized. If you love history, you will do very well! Every week there was both a quiz and discussion posts. The quizzes are very forward and discussion posts are graded on participation. The final exam was a final essay 4 pages long. Overall, I would recommend!
