Pretty straightforward class. Weekly quizzes are easy if you watched the lecture videos. Weekly discussion posts pretty much graded on completion. Essay based midterm and final are graded harshly so I would definitely put time into them.

Each week, there is a lecture and primary reading assignments, a short quiz, and a discussion thread. There is 1 midterm paper (2 page) and 1 final paper (4 page over two questions). I found this class extremely interesting and the lectures to be very accessible without background knowledge. Quizzes are super straightforward. Professor was great!

prob one of the easier history classes. i ended up not reading the book and did fine. as long as you watch the lectures with complete attention, you'll do good on the weekly quizzes. discussion posts are easy. midterm and final essays. lectures are kind of all over the place but again just pay attention.

You really dont have to use the textbook if you listen to his lectures he posts every week. pro tip: put it on 2x the speed and you'll be done with them in half the time. discussion posts and quizzes are not hard. Midterm and final can be graded semi-harshly and they are essay heavy. Just read the primary sources and listen to the lectures.
Dr. VanDerPuy does a great job at sending information and laying out what exactly he expects from his students. Follow his directions and you'll do just fine

This class had simple weekly quizzes but in order to do well on them you would have to listen to the lectures thoroughly. Also there was weekly reflections but those were easy. This class requires effort. Also the midterm was short answer and one essay question. The final was two essay questions. Overall I found this class pretty easy.

I took a class with Mr. Vanderpuy after seeing generally good reviews of him. However, his class was incredibly difficult, especially his weekly quizzes. Overall, Vanderpuy was not a good professor and I would not recommend that anyone take his class. Very disappointing

Class was almost completely discussion board based. Simple quizzes once a week and essay midterm and final. He seemed very enthusiastic and kind. Sent him an e-mail on the day our final was due, and he answered my question within a couple of hours. I used the book, but I probably could have gotten away with not using it. One of the easier A's.

Weekly discussion posts and quizzes with a midterm every few weeks. Lots of supplemental reading but its interesting and not necessary to be aware of every detail. Lectures are straightforward and interesting. Textbook is kind of dull but helpful.
Great professor, gives very informative lectures and is just amazing all the way around
really nice guy, super kind and easy to understand

Straightforward class, 2 exams, 1 term paper, and a participation/attendance grade. He posts a lot of readings on Carmen which you should look through to reference in your exams but otherwise not a bad class.

Easy class/GE because of the grading and way the class is set up. 1 paper, 2 midterms with cheat sheet and he gives the essays and possible ID terms before. Read the book, never went to class. His lectures are confusing, chaotic, and disorganized. Presents a lot of facts with little analysis or explanation of their significance.

I am a big fan of Professor Levi. His knowledge of the region is truly special and his personal accounts of many elements of the class make the course engaging. That said, it is a ton of reading and memorization. Also, the grading is very sporatic... I had a 96 until the day final grades were due with only 40 percent of grades in. Still loved it!

Mongol Empire is a good class, and I did take his other class, the Silk Roads. The movie days are just a punch in the face. Traveling over an hour by bus to get to class to watch a movie terrible. Just put it online, and I would watch it at home. There is so much to cover, and he doesn't cover all of it, making the papers and exams difficult.

you can get by skimming all 300 pages of reading each week. the syllabus says you have to buy 5 books, but only buy 4 out of the 5, if you are going to attend each lecture, don't need to buy the Peter Hopkirk book. great professor overall, but many classes were canceled. only grades are a 10-page paper, midterm and fina;, and extra credit optional

Awesome professor with a great personality as well - open to help if you ask for it. Lots of reading per week but not completely required to pass the class (can get by with skimming). Class is determined by a midterm, final, 10-page research paper, and map quiz, but not too strict with the grading. Amazing class and you learn a lot!

Lectures are good, when he shows up. Many lectures were cancelled, and two days were movie days.  Exams are mostly from the reading.  And there are 4-5 chapters and multiple research papers to read each week.

THERE IS A LOT OF READING, typically almost 200 pages a week, but the lectures are good. gives out good information during the lectures and is willing to answer any questions that students have. the course consists of a map quiz, a research paper (10 pages), 5 books, and access to the online Carmen page for secondary source information.
I will forever be grateful to have him as a professor. Haha Kentucky! Show up, do your part and he is very understanding. He really cares and very knowledgeable. Plus he hates ties so dont wear one��

Now, He is so caring and really wants his students to do well, but you have to want to do well. You have to read all the books he assigns in order to grasp the concept because his lecture is spoken. It's hard to know what is important. The only reason I did well was because I tried so hard for this class, especially for a GE. good luck.

Prof. Levi was one of the best history professors I've had. Very enthusiastic teacher who can make even dry and complex material interesting, understandable, and relevant. Definitely sparked my interest in Middle East history. (Simple) map quiz, midterm, final, and research paper. Gives helpful study guides a week before exams.

Super nice guy and is hands down the best professor i have ever had. Gets to know everyone on a first name basis and wants you to do well. Also super funny. Just go to class and take notes and you will be fine. Tried to take his other class but it was full :(

Levi is super knowledgable about the Middle East/Central Asia and incorporates lots of cool personal experiences into class. The lectures can be a little scattered without a powerpoint, but he gives a study guide before the exam. Exams definitely require studying but he gives you all the points he can. Helpful when it came to the research paper!
Professor Levi cares about students and is interested in your success. In class he is passionate about the material and tries to engage students. Absolutely wonderful professor!

Great professor. Engaging lectures, clear on information that is needed for tests, and overall an interesting man. Makes me look forward to the class and feel knowledgeable on the information when I leave. Very understanding and answers all questions expertly.

I had Breanna Miller as my TA and she was great. Biggest thing is to at least do part of the reading and participate once each recitation. It puts you in better standing with your TA if they know you are engaging in discussion. The tests weren't too hard, a terms list and 3 possible essays were provided beforehand to study. Take advantage of it.

i actually liked his lectures. exams were easy if you study. i got an A. all you have to do is go to his lectures and take notes. you will be good to go. oh reading helps too! some questions came from the book.

Lecture is all spoken, yes, but he always gives a list of terms at the beginning and it's not absurd to expect students to take notes during lecture. He's also VERY clear in what you need to know for the tests, gives a list of terms you need to know and a selection of essay questions, one of which will be on the test.

Professor Levi is a really cool guy, he tries to structure his class only on what interests students. He assigns books to read and my class did not like one of them so he told us we didn't have to read it. We only had one quiz (map quiz), one midterm, and one final (gives you essay prompts ahead of time). You also have to write an 8-10 page paper.

Horrible. No structure of class, is definitly not clear in what he wants you to know from the class for the test. Lecture is all spoken and this make it very hard to comprehand the information because these are names no one has heard of. Interesting info, but the class is overall terrible

I LOVED THIS CLASS.  He is hilarious, and he is an expert on anything and everything having to do with Central Asia.  We watched lots of movies, but I actually learned things from them.  There was one 10-page paper for the quarter.  The class was overall quite easy, and I would wholeheartedly recommend this class for the Mideast/Near East history.
Very, very, very passionate about the topic. Very knowledgeable about it too. Lectures felt like story-time, can get dry but mostly enjoyable. Humor lightens class
Great professor
He's one of the most knowledgable professors I've had, and about an obscure topic.  Even when his jokes aren't funny, they lighten up the class and make it a lot easier.

Great class!!!For someone not interested in history at all, with effort i pulled an A so its do-able. He is a great lecturer and funny with good timing. Just dont sit in the back cause he tends to mumble a bit. Lecture is basically the exam so a smart person would attend. And dont procrastinate on the paper i did and i lost a lot of sleep!

Awesome! I didn't know anything about the Middle East before taking this class and I learned a ton from him. Readings are mildly helpful, but his lectures are extremely thorough. Definitely need to go to class to get an A. Very fair exams! Any class would be great with him. He loves what he teaches.
Prof. Levi is a great guy and teaches a straightforward class. He is flexible with students in addition to the fact that he's always looking for student feedback. Take his class if you can.

If you need to take 398 and Levi is teaching, TAKE HIS CLASS. He is a cool dude, really funny. Assignments were relatively easy to stay on top of, and if you have any writing skills, you will ace the class.
Great guy and a great teacher

Professor Levi is a great guy. He does everything he can to help and loves to teach. He does require a lot of reading in his class, but it it is fairly easy and if you keep up on it, you are guaranteed a good grade.

Professor Arnold cares a lot about the success of her students and a lot about the material she teaches. That said, the class was a but unorganized and sometimes what she wanted was unclear. I do not blame her, as she is still adjusting to OSU, and I think she is a great instructor. Ask her questions!

Basically graded on the two essays which are 60% of your grade, responses and hypothesis assignments based on the material of that specific week. I thought she was nice and even though my essays were horrible I still got an A-. The class is at your own pace and there are no penalties for late assignments, but you should start early and not rush.

As a person she is very kind and it's easy to see she loves history. That being said this class is ONLY on Christian Saints. Do not take unless you are interested in learning about Christian Saints, enjoy a lot of reading, and write well. Tedious weekly assignments (graded hard, no feedback) and no slides/structure for lectures... only listening

One of the best classes I have taken. The love she had for Medieval History was palpable and made class amazing. She doesn't teach it chronologically; she teaches thematically so there is some jumping in the timeline. But she makes sure things are grounded. 6 papers that are 5 pages, but you can skip one. Overall great class with amazing professor

I feel like a lot of the people here giving her poor ratings are people who took one of her classes as a GE and were upset it wasn't just an easy A. She is genuinely one of the most caring and compassionate profs I have met and loves when students come to office hours. There is a good amount of reading and writing, welcome to the humanities.
Overall very unhelpful too hard of a grader for meaningless classes. Treats a GE class like your studying chemistry. Good luck❤️

I regretted almost every single lecture, they had no flow, no outline. I went to class with a bit of confusion about the reading and ended up with even more. If you are a person who knows a lot about Jesus and the Christian faith and sainthood, you will pass, if you don't DO NOT take this class!

Most of the course was taught through three assigned books. Lectures didn't follow a timeline and were all over the place or provided a brief snapshot in Roman history. Hypothesis assignments didn't teach much.

Extremely nice, but never gives clear instructions for assignments and little to no feedback when grading. The lectures have no relation to what we're working/being graded on and the attendance is ridiculous. She either talks like the class is 10 or already has a PhD, and not a single demon was discussed.

Dr. Arnold puts effort into her pedagogy. She cares about skill building, learning outcomes, and the wellbeing of students. Classes are a mix of lecture and discussion breakouts. You must read and attend class to make the pace manageable and succeed on graded work, but there's no wasted effort. Great prof and a brilliant and lovely person too.

Great professor who cares about her students, there is one big textbook that she uses throughout the semester and then there are 2 others that are used to supplement the big one. weekly source responses, no midterm but there is a massive final exam that is 10 pages but she breaks it up into four different sections

Mansoor is a great professor and is very knowledgeable and experienced on the topic of American Military History. This was just for my GE, but I ended up learning a lot and really enjoying the class.  Go to lectures and do the readings and you'll be good.  2 essays on the material as exams, 3 req books w/ essays, random graded attendance, and ex cr

Great professor who is very passionate about what he is teaching. Lectures can be very tedious and boring but overall have good info. TAs grade papers VERY tough, a midterm, final, and 2 book reviews and 5 random attendance checks. There was extra credit so that was nice. Overall not bad but only take if you rlly want to know in depth ww2.

Mansoor gave great and super thorough lectures, so if you paid attention, the essays were not terribly difficult, substance wise. The essays sometimes were difficult to write in the time span given, so you have to plan out your time pretty well. The TAs grade pretty harsh too, but use your notes and you should be fine.

Incredible course taught by an incredibly knowledgeable man. Could not have asked for a better experience in the class. Very few assignments - just a handful of essays that require you to be concise more than anything. Highly recommend to anyone interested in WWII, earning a history degree/minor, or looking for a fun but unburdening class.

If you're not smart like me but have work ethic you will pull an A- / B+. Study the study guides very well, didn't read much at all, pay attention in class, take more notes on what he says than the slides, Youll do fine

Peter is okay. His lectures are insightful for sure, just kind of boring. He is pretty full of himself and very opinionated. For example at one of his extra credit debates he was supposed to be a moderator and instead of doing so he interrupted one of the people debating to give his own opinion and shut the other persons down. His jokers are funny.

Professor Mansoor is by far my favorite professor at OSU. His lectures are worth attending even though they are not mandatory (he also takes random extra credit). Pay close attention to the rubrics and syllabus, and if you miss points on the papers make sure that you find out why to fix it, as some graders are pickier than others.

The best professor I have had at ohio state. Would take again, eish i still had the oppurtunity to take another one of hos classes. You have yo do the work, but theres no suprises and you know how your going to be graded. Amaxing man and amazing prof.

If you're interested in military history and you show up, you'll enjoy the class and do well. Professor Mansoor's knowledge and experience make his lectures very interesting and I learned a ton in his class. It is a lot of reading but you don't always have to do it, and the exams aren't bad.

One of the best professors at OSU. Sure the papers are difficult, but the books were so good and as long as you put in the extra effort you should be fine. The tests were straightforward from the study guides and they do grade the essays hard so prepare well for those. All in all, he is a wonderful professor and I can't recommend him enough!

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had at OSU. He is highly qualified for this job and his background makes his stories interesting and relative to course material. His dry sense of humor makes an already interesting class even more enjoyable! Read the book review books and follow the tips on Carmen and you will be fine.

He is probably the best professor I have had at OSU in my four years. He has an immense knowledge for the subject and makes the material very interesting. Not to mention, he is very respected in the historical community and in our government in general. If you have the chance to take one of his classes I would highly highly recommend it.

One of the poorest professors that I have ever had. He clearly knows what he is talking about but he speaks at you, not than to you. A former army officer and you can tell based on his better than you attitude. (Typical military officer). He reads off his own script that he wrights and spits info at you rather than teach you the information.

Lectures are excellent, Professor Mansoor is one of the most knowledgeable professors I've had, presents the class in an interesting way. Excellent credentials; if you like history you want to have the opportunity to learn from this guy. Exams require a good deal of studying, but you'll know exactly what's on the exam before hand.

I took his freshman seminar (Wars of 9/11) and I'm very glad I did. He is very knowledgeable of the material (and I mean VERY). It was incredible to learn from his perspective about modern Middle Eastern affairs. For his class we had a group project, a book report, and weekly class discussions. I learned a lot from him!

I had Prof. Mansoor for a Freshman seminar (Wars of 9/11) and it was extremely interesting. He is one of the most intelligent people I've ever met. He graduated first in his class at West Point and has more valuable military experiences than nearly anybody around. He knows what he is talking about, and has a sense of humor. Outstanding Professor!
Graded like an English class and very very military focused. Don't take this unless you have to

I loved Prof. Mansoor. His class was boring at first, but got a lot more interesting as we started talking about more current history. He makes jokes and adds a lot of quirky stories to his lectures. You have to write a book review, which was very tedious but I got an A. Two tests, studied hard and got an A on both. Challenging but enjoyable class.
He brought a lot of personal experience to the class.

I thought this class would be interesting but it was a very technical class. I found the reading difficult which also made it difficult to write the papers and essays since  I couldn't understand the reading. Prof. has a lot of military background which makes lectures and notes hard to understand if  you aren't familiar with military terms.

Fantastic professor and one of the best classes I've taken thus far at OSU. He makes all of the topics very clear and draws from an extensive military background to enhance lectures. However, there are book reviews assigned and they're graded very hard, so if you're not a solid writer it may be tougher. Tests are straight from the study guide
He comes off as being able to kill you at least 200 different ways and has a dry sense of humor that keeps lectures fun

Even as a history major, I thought this class was very difficult. It is graded in the form of an English class: there are two book reports and several essays on each exam. Also, do not make the mistake that I did thinking that this is a history of World War II. It is actually very military based, which I was not interested in at all.

He is a good professor but why in the hell is writing book reports the most important thing in a History class. I would not recommend taking the class unless you are a very good writer, they grade very hard.

Prof was very educated on WWII and has ppts posted online from day 1, which makes it easy to look over notes. I did little reading for the class; much was assigned. Read the books for the book review and follow advice posted on Carmen to do well. Exams followed his provided study guide 100% and there we no surprises. Easy class and pleasant prof.
Very interesting lectures. Book reviews were graded tough, along with exams.  Content was great along with the professor's background in the military.

Phenomenal lecturer with tons of real world experience. He's very passionate about the subject and is extremely helpful when it comes to grading and preparing for exams. TA's do most of the grading, and are usually very available despite the larger class. Would recommend to anyone.
Very good professor. Super interesting class. Attend the class, and follow along in lecture and you'll be fine!

He's always open to questions, very organized, and he's really good at getting the facts across in an interesting way! You can definitely tell he knows what he's talking about, and his humor makes the class even better! I definitely recommend taking this course!

He's great! The class was very strategic focused but he made it easy to understand. I was already extremely interested in the subject so that helped too. Assignments weren't horrible and his humor really made the class enjoyable.
Great class and great professor!

One of my favorite classes I've taken so far. Respectable guy. I learned a great deal from this class- the lectures were very clear, and he stayed consistent with the slides/syllabus (very organized). The exams are difficult, but if you attend class, take good notes and study, you won't regret taking the class!
Great teacher and teaches a great class.  If you attend lecture and do the work you'll get a good grade.  He gives you a study guide that the test pretty much comes from. I loved this class.

I found this class to be extremely hard, even though I am a history major. You must attend all the classes and read all the texts, which is mind numbing and very time consuming. This is because he assigns roughly 150 pages a night, not including the 3 extra book reviews you have to write. Unless you do exactly what he wants, expect a low grade.

Prof. Mansoor is a great professor. He really knows his subjects and is incredibly helpful. I didn't really use the books in either class I took, but they can help you some on the tests. Make sure to follow his guidelines on papers to the letter. You will have to work for a good grade on the papers but the tests aren't bad at all.
He was a fabulous professor. Definitely recommended. He is passionate about history regarding the military. You will have to work for your grade but if your a history buff as I am...great class!

I had Professor Mansoor for the History of WWII. He made the lectures very interesting, and had a comedic flair that kept the class constantly amused (the man does a hilarious Hitler impression). However, he has a high standard of grading, and what may get you an A in someone else's class may only get you a B. I'd recommend attending all classes.

The class is tough. Read the book, all lectures are based off of every chapter of the book, if you don't read and never find this out your a moron. Go to class and make sure it is clear in exams.  Not hard if you do these things

I had Prof. Mansoor for both 307 and 582- and I'm not a History major or military enthusiast. Not only did I learn a lot, but my writing also improved as a result of the class.  You will definitely have to work for your grade, but it is worth it!  I highly recommend either class.

I really enjoyed this class. Not an easy grader at all,   but he knows so much about military history and he always had interesting comments and stories to share. I would recommend this class, but you definitely have to be interested in WWII!

If you're not an ROTC geek or Historian then RUN AWAY NOW!!! I would rather see Dr. Kavorkian than see Dr. Mansoor. This is only for ate up military folks. If you don't wear camoflauge underware this isn't for you.
Professor Mansoor is an interesting teacher. I felt like I learned a lot from his class and would recommend it to anyone interested in taking it.
He's very clear and to the point. He's interested in the topic and knows what he is talking about. I would definitely recommend for someone to take a class that he teaches.

I think he is a good professor overall. He does tend to read straight from his notes, though I doubt it's Wikipedia - he is a Colonel and knows what he's talking about. It can make it slightly boring, but still interesting if you like WWII, and I have learned a lot. He doesn't tolerate dumb questions or sleeping in his class - he'll kick you out.

As someone who only hopes to be a Marine officer, I was extremely intimidated by him at first. Then, I realized how awesome of a guy he is. His jokes are a good break from his lectures. The lectures are very lengthy and contain a ton of information. Take a ton of notes to do well on his written finals. 350 characters does not give him justice.

Prof. Mansoor is a very interesting guy, and he's really blatant about mistakes made by military and political leaders. The material is really fun to learn, and Prof. Mansoor chose interesting books for the course. I would definitely recommend this course, and this professor.

Overall the content of this class was very interesting. It was a mix of powerpoint lectures and documentaries. There was reading but I never got to it. Even the comparative book review I just skimmed the books. The exams were straightforward but the final exam was way too long. I would say 75% of the class was still there when the exam time ended.

Must take class for anyone interested in WWII. The lectures were very interesting with the pictures and the documentary footage. Both exams are straightforward, he tells you what to study and if you study the terms you should do fine. No textbook, just powerpoints. My only complaint is the required reading is unrealistic, way too much.

Professor Mansoor is pretty awesome. Lectures can be pretty boring, but he shows alot of movies, trys to be funny at times, and always takes the time to help. The only downside to this class was the TA. She seemed to enjoy showing off how much she knew and talking down to people like they were 5 year olds rather than actually helping.

WONDERFUL class! Need to go to lectures because his slides are just a backhbone, but very interesting. Only a midterm/paper/final--but a study guide is given for the midterm and final. Paper is fine if you do the readings. A must take for a histsory major or anyone interested in WWII.

I loved taking history 286 with Dr Watkins. Yes I know I it says 460 above. It was a very entertaining class. If you don't like reading this class probably isn't right for you. our grade was determined by 3 papers and 2 mapping. In that even if you suck at Geography,,, like myself you will do fine. It's really easy.

This class was very free form - students picked a week and a topic to lead the 3 hour discussion on. You read a lot, but nothing crazy for a reading seminar. Her grading criteria is loose as well, in general participate a lot and you will only help your grade. 20 page final paper in addition to your discussion week also determine grade

The readings were the only good thing. The presentations are messy and barely put together (A whole week of lectures had no audio). Written midterm and final with no clear rubric or topic, just "write until you think you've written enough." Papers weren't that bad, but too much for a 2000 level class when paired with the written midterm and final.

Extremely condescending. Lectures were messy (filled with rants and barely put together Prezi slides). Doing too much for a second-session course- a 10 page paper is unnecessary in addition to a written midterm and final. Overall, it was a simple but disappointing class. Would never take this professor again.

A strict professor when it comes to deadlines. This is second session course, fast paced in my opinion. Make sure to complete your assignments ahead of time. I would advise you to take every single assignment seriously. The midterm is worth 15% and the final exam 20%. Both exams are essays. The 10-15 page final paper seems too much.

she does weekly reading discussions which are 20-200 pages long, also has a 10 page final due at the end of the class as well as the readings, a written mid term and final. I took history classes before but she expected too much in a session 2 course. Don't take if you're a stem major.
Overall seemed very disinterested in the course. Was difficult to reach when I had questions and was very unclear when it came to due dates with assignments not aligning with the syllabus.

Lots of reading every week. There's not many points throughout the semester, the biggest chunk of grades are towards the end so no matter how good you're doing, it could change easily. However, she is a lenient grader. The topics she asks you to write on are very specific.

She's okay but her grading criteria is very unclear and the entire class is just all around dry. There are four weeks left in the semester and I don't feel that I've learned anything. Take another GE if you have the option.

This professor expects way too much. The amount of work we have to do each week is insane. For example 3 hours of online lecture and 120 pages of reading. The reading were actual books, not textbooks, but it was challenging and took me and hour to read 35 pages. Idk how really expects her students to do 7 hours worth of work per week plus studying

Do not take her. Before this class I was passionate about learning American Indian history since I have taken classes on it before and loved it, after this class, it ruined my passion. Its unfortunate how a bad instructor can ruin something for you. She is condescending and unhelpful. Acts better than everyone. Many spelling errors, as well.

Does not care about her students. She was condescending. She put the wrong due dates on assignments and then does not take fault for it. Would not recommend this professor at all. She should not be working as a professor with her lack of professionalism. The work is not hard at all, she just does not assume responsibility for her faults.

I don't know about some of you graders but I have to laugh when someone had to read 40 pages per week and thought that was extremely difficult.  She picks out really good books and her lectures are well done.   So would take any of her courses again.  Better than most I have seen.

I have been at OSU for 3 years & this is the worst professor I've had.  She claims she is available for questions but when you take the time to reach out to her she is condescending and unhelpful.  I did more work for this class than my major (40 pages of reading per week) and struggled to get good grades.  Don't take this class, you'll regret it.

Insane amounts of reading and unclear guidelines for assignments. Grades seem entirely arbitrary, and if you ask her about what you did wrong in order to improve, she not only cannot give any good reason for her grading, but has such horrible grammar/writing skills that her responses  make no sense at all. Not sure how she got to OSU, but... avoid.

This professor has the most unrealistic expectations ever. Im an a  senior nursing  student and usually do well in classes and I'm not a stranger to a high work load but she expects so much reading its cry worthy. AVOID THIS CLASS. When you ask for help she puts little in addressing concerns. She's the most useless professor I've had.

I am in her online class, and she seems like a very good teacher; however, this class makes me do more work than my major classes combined. There is so much reading and work to do for just a GE class. Would not recommend.

This class was really interesting because she really made sure to teach the untold stories and causes behind the american revolution. There are 2 midterms and 1 paper,  but none were difficult if you came to class or met with your history study group to discuss beforehand (she makes the groups based on personality which was really cool).

Melissah is a great professor. You can tell she truly loves her job and it shows! However, I felt as though this class was taken too seriously for a GE. I worked very hard in this class, spent more time in here then classes related to my major (studied daily, started papers 2 weeks early) and still received grades lower than expected.

Melissah is a great professor that truly cares about the success of her students. She uses Prezi instead of powerpoint which can get cluttered, but she makes lectures interesting. You sign in to every lecture and can only miss one, but this is a huge grade booster. She always makes herself available to help and is very passionate. Would recommend!

Without a shadow of a doubt the best possible history teacher, I have had in my career as a student. Enthusiastic, caring, and most importantly smart, this teacher encompasses every quality of a perfect teacher. Despite a rigorous work load, this teacher manages to help every student individually to create the best versions od themselves. 10/10
God tier teacher
Worst teacher ever

He is always overly-excited about coming to class and teaching. Blasts music beforehand. Some heavy reading in the upper level courses, but as others have said, he makes it all clear and easy. Take him.

His classes were usually interesting. He is always excited to teach which makes you come to his classes. He also gives out the study guide-just review them, you'll do fine on his exams. There were quizzes and a paper...very manageable.
Absolutely incredible.

This was his first time teaching 152 but taught it well. He was easy to understand and interesting, unlike many other history profs. You can tell he loves history and even if you don't like the subject, he still makes the class bearable.

He was THE best history teacher I have ever had! I was pleasantly surprised by his lecture methods and he made every class worth coming to, by his stories and ways of teaching.  I highly recomend him!

Matt was a fantastic teacher! Go to class and write down everything he says and you will do great in the class. There is some reading, but he talks about it class so you always understand it. He is really excited about history, and wants to help all the students. Class and office hours were helpful, and never boring.

Awesome Professor!!! Teaches subject matter you've been learning since 2nd grade but manages to keep the class interesting! He's truly passionate about what he's teaching which helps you stay awake during the hour and 48 min lecture!  I definitely recommend him! Thanks matt!
Outstanding instructor - highly recommended!  Helps in out anyway he can...shame there's not more like him at OSU!  Cheer's Matt :-)
Great teacher... makes a fairly dull subject interesting. Office hours are extremely helpful. Fair grader, not an easy A but simple to get a good grade if you put the time in.
One of the most interesting guys. You can tell he actually cares about and is very interedted in what he is teaching. Not boring at all..overall chill guy. Recommend.
Best teacher I've ever had. You can tell he loves what he does and academia hasn't yet sucked the life out of him! Great at making Puritan New England interesting. Highly recommend.

he is the most positive person ever. even with an incorrect answer he makes it seem like the person was right. grades papers kind of hard for a GEC but has a good review policy that should be taken advantage of. good guy and a good teacher, and has a very very broad taste of music that he will talk about in class. p.s. he WILL be late to class.

He is extremely friendly and helpful- try and get him as your TA! He loves History and it sounds corny but it makes you (as uninterested as you may be about the subject) like it more, too. He understands that not everyone is a history major and is SO helpful and lenient when grading. One of the only GECs I didn't mind going to. 100% recommended!
He is the best will help with anything and is always available if needed
He was the best TA ever! so funny, helps you with whatever you need help with. he makes the quizzes and papers so easy! If you can, get Matt as your TA. me makes this class.
No Comments

AWESOME TA. He was a TA for Dr. Hegarty, and let me tell you, he made history bearable for those of us who hate history.  And he was WAY more than willing to help with papers, studying, questions, whatever.  Props to Matt.  He's awesome.

Only grades certain assignments for credit in Carmen, extremely hard grader! Be prepared to read every week and participation in class matters. Pop quizzes on readings and films almost every week with obscure questions that you must watch/ read the material to catch on. Nice, knowledgeable guy however.

Clay is one of the best professors I've had so far. His lectures are great and he provides a lecture guide paper to fill in if you so wish. His feedback on essays is amazing and I feel like he really helped me become a better writer, highly recommend taking a class with him your first year. On top of all this, he's just a great dude!

Clay is FANTASTIC and hands-down the best professor I have had at OSU so far. He is a tough grader, but also gives so much feedback and is happy to meet. There is also a lot of homework, but there wasn't a single reading or video that I thought wasn't necessary. He is also hilarious and I will never stop recommending taking a class with Clay.

He is a fantastic lecturer and he really cares about his students. He can be a very particular grader but I have never seen someone give as much feedback as him. He left me a full 10-minute audio recording breaking down my paper and explaining what was good and bad about it. Very available to talk outside of class and gets to know his students.

Clay was an awesome professor and this class was super interesting and I felt like I learned a lot. While the papers were graded tough, he gave clear and direct expectations and was more than willing to help you out at every step. Feedback was also individualized and helped. It developed me as a better writer. He is also hilarious.

This is my second class I've taken with Clay. He is one of the best professors in the history department in my opinion. If you are interested in urban or LGBTQ history, he is a great professor to learn from. Expect weekly writing practices, readings, group project, and at least two essays. He is a tough but fair grader and gives great feedback.

Clay is an amazing lecturer. He really cares about his students. But you must do the reading and homework and he moves really quickly. He is also a tough grader... idk anyone who got an A in my class.

Clay was an engaging professor who likes to crack jokes and obviously loves what he teaches. As other people have said, there's an insane amount of reading each week but he gives you the whole week to finish the readings. He's a really tough paper grader, and you'll most likely have to adjust your writing style to his expectations to get an A.

Clayton is definitely the best professor I've had during my time at OSU. The readings can be a bit much but are always interesting. He is a tough paper grader but gives excellent feedback and is always available outside of class if you need help or just want to chat. The discussions may seem intimidating but participation becomes easier over time.

Dr. Howard was one of the best I've had at OSU. He's very funny, super knowledgable, and lets his personality show through. There are discussions every Friday with a lot of assigned reading. There were three papers over the course of the semester, but no exams. He maybe graded the papers a little harder than other profs, but gave great feedback.

So the pros: Clay is very knowledgable on urban history, incorporates a variety of sources, humorous at times, and organized. Cons: very tough paper grader, takes a while to grade said papers, is very discussion heavy (likes to call out people), sarcastic, often interjects personal opinions as fact Class was reading heavy, understandably.
His class was ok, he's a really tough grader when it comes to papers. At least you'll get a good laugh in class.

Clay had been one of the best profs I've had at OSU so far. He engages the class in critical thinking and interesting discussions. The reading were awesome also. He is very funny and easy to talk to. He is a fair grader and supportive.

Would take another class with him. He is a great professor and makes the class very enjoyable. History is not my best class but I enjoyed taking this class with Clay. If you have the option of online or in class with Clay, take it with Clay. He really cares about this class and makes it interesting!!
Lots of readings but learned a lot from his class, participation in class is important, went to the University of Michigan but deep down knows that Ohio State is better
Lots of reading due every week. There were 3 papers that weren't bad. No tests. Clay is a great professor. I generally dislike history but actually enjoyed this class. Would definitely recommend.

I learned so much from this class, I think everyone should take it. That said, it's a whole lot of work each week for the Friday discussion class, and he grades pretty hard on essays (in my experience). He's an engaging lecturer, though, and I think everyone likes him.

Clayton Howard is the man. Every lecture was interesting, and Clay loves to answer questions, and constantly change the pace of the lecture to keep students engaged. My only complaint is there is a lot of reading for this class, which is a bummer, since I took it to fill a GE requirement. Bottom Line: World class lecturer, unnecessary work load
Clay Howard is an amazing Professor. One of the best that I've had so far at OSU. He's hilarious and actually knows how to teach. Would definitely take him again!
Prof Howard is great! It's a reading intensive class and it was a lot of work but I really enjoyed it and I would definitely take another class with him!

the teaching style is demeaning, constantly making broad belittling comments towards the whole class for not doing well on assignments. he expects everyone to master Chinese history before taking the class. expects so much from the students while not teaching. 4 books, one midterm, only have the take the final exam if you fail the midterm.

Proff Reed is someone that i have genuinely come to dislike. He is very rude to students and does not take criticism well. After failing almost the entire class on a MIDTERM paper he turned it into a lecture and scolded us when his lectures and class materials are irrelevant and teach you nothing. He expects you to know everything and doesnt teach

He was a good professor but was very strict to the point where he has it if you record or take any photos of his lecture you will get reported for academic misconduct. Also, do not miss any class or assignments sd he does not accept any excuse other than big emergencies with proof.
do not take. 0/10

He can be super condescending and picky. He is really just looking for you to write about what he wants to see and hear. He sometimes jumps to conclusions and never really explains how you get to that conclusion and is constantly picking points that fit his agenda in the class. not objective. and he goes bell to bell every lecture which is hard.
He's very very picky, ended up dropping the class because it was so ridiculous. I heard if you go to office hours he's more lenient but overall just a bad lecturer.
Loves to talk and help students out, will listen to anything you have to say and provide quality feedback.

Very knowledge about the subject material, but conveys the information in a way that students can understand. You can tell that he cares about his students not just learning the material but understanding the causes and effects. Overall, the best professor I've had at OSU.

You can tell Ian cares about teaching--he is knowledgeable and enthusiastic. He blended lecturing with photos, videos,  and interesting stories--I feel like I lived through the Russian Revolution. He encouraged discussion and went out of his way to help students. I wish I could take every history class with him.
For a 100 level GEC he graded papers and exams like a masters thesis.  Really boring class too, straight from power points.  If attendance wasn't apart of the grade I would have skipped every day,

Professor Akin was amazing! I took this course last year but it was very memorable. Professor Akin's lectures are long, but he makes them super entertaining and engaging. He's super knowledgeable and highlights a topics importance very well. Overall he's a great professor and I highly recommend!

Dr. Akin makes funny jokes and his lectures are entertaining yet educational, and he grades very fairly. There is a great deal of reading required for his class. Additionally, attendance is not mandatory, but it is crucial as he goes much more in-depth in his lectures than what is available in the slideshows.

In many ways, your experience in Dr. Akin's class will depend on how much effort you put in; if you do your readings and show up to class prepared to learn and discuss, this class could be your best yet. During my time at OSU, I've never had a professor challenge me as much as this class, with real effort rewarded in learning and in your grades.
Dr Akin was very compassionate, had a great sense of humor, the lectures were phenomenal, and he will help you in any way possible. Definitely recommend his classes.

Most compelling course I have ever taken. Also one of the heaviest workloads I have ever had, but Dr. Akin is extremely accommodating and helpful if you show effort/interest and work in good faith. He's a really solid prof all-around.

Dr. Teague was super nice and responded to emails really quickly. You do have to get the books for this class to write the papers and discussion posts, but if you take the 4-week summer course you can get the work done in time to return them for a full refund :) Good history GE class.

Professor McDow is a good lecturer. Although, he gets very emotional while lecturing, which can undermine his claims to be presenting information impartially. Overall, the class structure is good but the first half of the semester has a ton of reading. Good way to get a history credit without too much writing.

McDow is a great lecturer! I really enjoyed this class. Be aware- it is a history and a microbio class. You learn both. It's not necessarily easy, but if you study you'll be alright. They provide focus questions and clear rubrics so nothing is shocking. The group project is difficult, but try your best and you'll be alright.

Good lecturer, doesn't assign a crazy amount of work. Passionate about teaching and wants you do well. Occasionally posts lecture slides. Occasional quizzes on geography. Good grader. Midterm and Final were good.

Slow grader. Harsh grader. Not a fun class. My advisor convinced me this would be a casual low-intensity course that I could take with more rigorous ones. Instead, this course drained me and required a lot of my attention. There is a group project that is just so bad and nerve-racking. The EXAM is ~20 long response questions. Avoid this course.

Hes a nice person. but I found him very annoying as a teacher. This class was way too much work for a gen ed, even for honors. I got an A, but the class was much more history heavy than I was wanting, and the level of outside work and reading was ridiculous for a 3 credit hour course, let alone a gen ed. Do NOT take this class as a gen ed.

Overall enjoyed my two classes with him (I also took Hist/Micro 3704). My only comments are that his grading criteria is not always clear and he can be very hard to access via email at times. If you do the work on time and try to follow his instructions as much as possible, you should be able to succeed.
I took a second class with him because of how much I enjoyed this class! Definitely recommend.
Prof McDow is an amazing and very understanding man. I would recommend taking a course with him.

Do not skip class. If you miss even one without a note you will drop a letter grade. I never missed, but people in my class told me about it. There is homework but he flips a coin on if you turn it in or not. Tough grader on papers but he will help you whenever it is needed. Honestly, he is a great professor and a great guy.

Dr. McDow is awesome! I really enjoyed his class, thought he was very helpful and taught well. However, it was a lot of work for a GE. Don't take this class if you have no intrinsic interest in the subject. DO THE READING. There is a lot and it is challenging but he breaks it down in class. The midterm and final are based around it!

Nice guy but talks WAY too much and takes over. It's really only his class. There were 2 simple questions about the virus itself on the exam, then McDow's portion (85%) of the exam was long, and you had to read long stories and write essays. If you want a science course, this isn't it. It's literally ALL history. Lots of papers, and a presentation.

McDow is super nice and cares about his students.  That being said, as a history minor I've never had to do so many assignments for one class.  There's a project that spans the whole semester and you basically write like 9 papers that say the same thing.  It's a very repetitive class, and McDow can often be scattered and confusing in lecture.

Professor McDow was Ok....I didn't really like his teaching/question style. He talks extremely fast and is very unclear of what he wants you to know from his lecture. His portion of the tests were also way too long and confusing. Definitely not my favorite professor, but not my least favorite. **LOTS of group work and outside reading/reflections**

I can't explain the impact Professor McDow had on my classroom experience! He was always interested in any outside research we completed and was very through in his explanations. He made sure that the students completely understood the material before leaving the classroom, and if they asked a question that he did not know, he would research it

He's a nice guy but a mediocre teacher. Lectures were very boring and coupled with his rather annoying voice they weren't very fun. He is not very clear in what he wants from you. He is a pretty tough grader on papers and the weekly quizzes. If you are looking for an easy History GE I would advise you take something else with another professor.
Funny, informative and enthusiastic. I actually looked forward to lectures.
Great Prof, really interested in his subject, and tried to interact with the students in different ways, some of which were kind of cheesy, but was one of the best classes I took.

The best professor I have ever had. You will not find a better history professor. Go to class and discussion and this class will be easy for you. If you don't good luck. Gives you exam information ahead to time, even the subject of the essay for the exam. He won a teaching award in class on day for being such a good teacher in the department. 11/10

Genvoa is probably the best history teachers at OSUM. He makes the topics enjoyable and has one of the easiest classes available. All that was needed was a 5 sentence discussion board, a 10-page paper (you have all semester to work on it and he will help), and the exams. Really nice guy and you should take any classes he has for a grade boost.
6 books required for this course!

I really liked this class...can be a bit boring at times b/c he can talk for days but about really interesting information..he's a cool guy and is willing to help if u ask. he tells u exactly whats on the quizzes and exams (& map quizzes)--soooo easy. overall---good prof.!!! i would most def. recommend him w/out a doubt!

Painfully socially awkward, and hard to hear, you're embarassed for him the whole time he talks.  You'd think he'd be sweet, being so shy and nerdy, but he's actually quite unfriendly and has no time for you.  Self-interested.  His progressive politics are at odds w/ his nastiness to people he meets in real life.
Wow, this guy is intense.  Not in a good way.
this prof was great.  he is very knowlegdable about the class material, and he taught me so much about African history.
Fantastic teacher. Excellent class.

This was a pretty good class! Most assignments were easy to finish in one sitting, but most lectures were about 15 minutes long and each section had 3-5 lectures to watch. This was his online class, so it is most likely different from his in-person class. There were about 3 essays for the entire class, one being the final. All of which were easy.

Grading criteria is unclear. Lectures often don't relate to what you're graded on. 

Rambles. Snarky and often rude. My least favorite class so far.
The guy has a massive superiority complex.
By far the worst professor I've at Ohio State. Mocks and belittles students for asking questions. The tests and papers he gives are nearly impossible to pass. I heavily recommend not taking him.

Nightmarishly difficult grader who speaks with a constant aura of condescension. It's clear that he doesn't care about student success. If this wasn't bad enough, the assignments givens are far above what should is generally expected in a ~3000 class, and the rubric is non-existent.

Finished 3501 with a C.

Good luck getting an A. You'll need it.

Hitory3501 is great, would take it with Prof. Parrott. He is always there to help you and will do his best to make sure you succeed. Show up to lectures and talk in discussions, and ASK questions because he will answer them and help you actually learn. Would take another one of his classes. The negative reviews are his online section so, inperson >

Prof Parrott was very helpful throughout the course. It is clear that he wants his students to succeed greatly and he even offers a number of extra credits to help your grade out. He was honestly the best prof when it came to writing assignments too since he gives great advice and will recognize the effort you put in. Definitely a 10/10

I have fairly severe ADHD, which tends for me to speak fast and occasionally get caught up in what I'm saying. In this class, you have to be correct in everything you say to avoid embarrassment. I enjoyed the content material, and engaged in it to better learn, however I was in fear the whole class of messing up. He embarrasses you when wrong.

This is my first history course but there was just the vibe that if I said something wrong, he would judge me hardcore. Lots of reading that I didn't do but literally all your essays are based off the readings. Interesting course but just wish there wasn't tests lol.

Despite the less than stellar rep on this page, I really enjoyed this class. His lectures were concise and informative, and none of the homework was overly complicated or too long. This class is pretty comprehensive in terms of what you learn, so I would only take this class if you were genuinely interested in it. Good guy with unfair reviews.

Some of the reading assignments were way too long, especially considering this was taken as an accelerated course and we needed to do two weeks of work in one. He also expected us to learn more from the readings than we did from the lectures, as his lectures were very general and he wanted more specific discussion details than what he provided.
The class itself was intriguing, but he comes off as very full of himself. He assigns an impossible amount of reading and is a very tough grader. I like challenges but I would not take him again.

His lectures are great. You can clearly tell that he loves the subject but I swear to god. The little pop quizez that he gives and homework assignment are way too difficult for an undergrad class. Like it literally makes no sense go the little things to be so difficult. And he is not actually willing to help students at all even though he says so.

One of the worst classes I have had the displeasure of taking. Great lecturer and is clear that he is well informed on the content of the course but it is also clear he has no interest in the success of his students. Assignments were unnaturally difficult and there were no opportunities for improvements. DO NOT RECOMMEND ANY CLASS WITH HIM.
He's a good guy and an interesting lecturer. Reading quizzes were unnaturally hard and the TA's grading was horrible.
Definitely not easy for an intro course but I learned a lot in very little time. Markus had clear expectations and if you like history this is a good choice!

I'm a history major and this class has been my least favorite. Super tough grader with tough assignments. For an online summer class this was way too writing heavy with a crazy heavy grading scale and the quizzes have the worst questions.

I thought I would hate it since I study PE, but I actually really liked this class. Schoof does not mess around and is tough but also fair. I learned more than in most other classes I have taken in my 4 years at OSU.

Professor Schoof is a really good and fair professor. His grading criteria is tough, but he gives really good feedback, and if you listen to it, there's no doubt you'll do well in this course. I definitely wouldn't say this is an easy A GE course, but if you're willing to put in the time and effort, you can really get a lot out of this class!
I thought this was a great class! Marcus answers messages quickly and tries to make things exciting. My favorite was the discussions, especially about recent history!

The only good thing I have to say, is his feedback on discussion boards and essays is very helpful. His lectures are boring, he assigns 5+ terrible quality youtube videos each week along with the lecture. Also, his weekly quizzes have the worst multiple choice questions I have ever seen, would not recommend for your history GE.

As long as you take good notes on lectures and key ideas for readings, it's really not too bad. Had to learn the hard way that he is anal about citations so provide those and you will be fine. Learned a lot!

4-week intro history class granted it was 4 weeks so the workload was more jam-packed than a regular semester. Provided irrelevant readings and was not clear in what to pay intention to in said readings. Graded on 4 quizzes/4 discussions, midterm paper and final paper. All were toughly graded for intro course. Dont take if looking for easy course

Schoof's an amazing professor and provides in-depth feedback on discussions and papers. The class is completely asynchronous with weekly discussions and quizzes about that week's reading and lecture. It is vital that you read the assigned stuff since he requires citations in the discussion but that is the only real pain. Take notes on his lectures!

Markus has been awesome! When I was going through some difficulties, he was understanding and helped me understand how to write better. I am not a "history guy" but it was a great class even though it was too much reading for my taste ��

Prof. Schoof is one of my favorite instructors here at OSU. I am not a history major but he really made it on grow on me. Might minor in it one day! He can be tough but it gets easier over time since he gives great feedback on assignments. The audio of lectures can be muffled but you get used to it lol Really sweet guy!

At first, I was frustrated because I never got the discussion score I thought I deserved. But Schoof gave me individual feedback for each of my 12 discussion posts. In the end, I figured out how to write better and use sources and got As. Interesting class, even though I am not a big fan of history. Schoof is a tough but fair professor.

This was a really good course. We started in colonial times and covered pretty much all of Latin America in the 19th century and 20th century. I knew little beforehand but had no problem. And wow, I had no idea how much the US interfered in Latin America! Quizzes can be hard. Discussions were easy. Papers were fair but took much time. Good class

This online class initially took me by surprise. The workload felt a bit heavy. However, as you get in the flow of doing the discussions and readings it gets easier each week. Schoof will not give you an A on discussions for simply summarizing the readings. He wants you to engage with the material and form your own argument. Def learned a ton!

I really enjoyed this class with Dr. Schoof. If you do the readings and pay attention to his recordings, this course is really not too challenging. 13 quizzes and discussions, but he only counts the best 10. Two large essays. It is definitely more work then other intro classes but I feel like I have also learned so much about the 20th century.

Often posted the material late and used inconsistent quiz policies (able to take every quiz twice, could sometimes view which questions were missed). Weekly readings, weekly quizzes, 2 weekly discussion posts, 1 essay midterm, and 1 essay final. Required 3 textbooks, which is a little ridiculous for an introductory course. Answers emails quickly.

If you are thinking about taking his class for an easy GE, don't. This is easily the most difficult class I have taken here so far and I am a 4th year. If you do not know every detail given in his lectures you will do poorly on the quizzes. He does not give clear grading criteria and will take off points if you do not follow his unclear rules. RUN.

Professor Schoof is a great guy that has a passion for teaching. He is funny and tries to make boring lectures a little entertaining. Attendance is required and if you dont go to lectures quizzes and exams will be difficult. There were 4 quizzes, a midterm, analytical paper, and a final. Clear guidelines are set for the paper and exams.

This was one of the hardest classes I ever took. I learned a lot about our history but this was not an easy class. Mr. Schoof really pushes you to your limits. I am glad I took the class but this was not a simple class to get an A. Definitely recommend him but do not take the class if you are hoping for an easy grade, even though it's online!!

Markus is a good guy. There were five not-that-hard quizzes, a midterm, a paper, a final, and then a small participation grade (plus some extra credit sprinkled in). The exams are kind of difficult, but fair. I enjoyed the class and am actually taking another one with Markus in the fall. If you have the chance, I recommend taking him.
Nice guy. Made class fun and I learned a lot. More readings than I would like but overall interesting materials. Assignments require time but are very much doable. Would recommend.

Emailed him a week before class started telling him I needed to take his class to stay on track to graduate early, and he replied he wouldn't over enroll his ONLINE class. Eventually got in anyway, and was easiest A of my college career. Only multiple choice quizzes/final. Clearly recycled Q's/lectures. Don't expect him to help you get in his class

Very easy courses. As a 4-week session 3 course, Dr. Wood deleted final paper and discussion boards wisely, which makes the course very easy. After reading all papers and watching assigned videos, you will have a good grade! Very easy GE theme citizenship!
History 3014 is a very simple 4-week course. The only tasks are the online quizzes and exams. Choose it, and you will be very easy to complete GE theme citizenship.

Mr. Wood is a very kind professor. He set the course very simple. All grades are based on the online quizzes and exams, so if you take a look of his lecture recording, you will get a very easy A to complete GE theme citizenship!
friendly, clear grading criteria, not much work, straightforward

Very easy class for the GE credit. Minimal Work, just one big research paper, but you'll have plenty of time to do it. He's a nice guy, and my grade stayed at an A the entire semester. Definitely would choose this for an easy GE Theme credit.

Just a weird class in general. It was a second session semester class but all the lectures and quizzes still felt rushed. The midterm/final are just recycled quiz questions and you get the feeling this professor doesn't really put in any work into making this course. One big paper at the end which was harshly graded for no reason with no feedback.

Really chill online class. The professor was super helpful during online office hours and answering emails. The class does take up a bit of your time, but it is a very easy A as long as you put in any type of effort. Bi-weekly modules with reading tests and one paper that wasn't so bad. Highly recommend it as an elective history class.

I had Dr. Wood online so I wasn't really able to develop a relationship with him. His class was easy, 4 quizzes a week, but they were nothing hard. As long as you do the readings and watch the videos this class is an easy A. He also gives practice quizzes that are the same as the real quizzes so there's no reason not to pass this class.

I took as a session 2 class online. Every week, we had two modules consisting of a practice lecture exam, practice reading exam, lecture exam, and reading exam. You were able to take the practice exams as many times as needed to score 100%. There is a midterm, final exam, and final paper -- all not too bad. Would definitely take again!

Generous with deadlines which was great especially during the shift to this new online class format and he responds quickly to emails. Lots of lecture videos, they move a bit slow but they're recorded, quite a bit of reading as well. Had 3 major final assignments. The content is not difficult but the class moves through a lot of material quickly.

One of the worst profs I ever met. He had almost no interest in helping. His instructions were confusing and hard to understand esp for the paper and project. He gives too many lectures (16+ a week) and theyre difficult to watch. I watched them 2-3 times and didnt learn a thing. You can't use outside sources for the project when his sources suck.

This class is a lot of busy work. He is a fairly easy grader and seems to want the students to learn. That being said I do not think this course is really teaching anyone anything. He does not seem passionate about this course. I feel like having a final paper, final exam and a final project is a lot to push in the last week of the semester

I never liked history, but this class made me like it. Really well organized online class and great lectures from Professor Wood. Good and timely feedback. Clearly some students are bitter judging by some of the reviews, but I've talked to many classmates and I'm not alone in thinking he's awesome.

Group projects, , , in the middle of a pandemic? Doesnt sit right with me. Its not a lot of work and you dont get much interaction from him. Overall his weekly messages rubbed me the wrong way. Personally he felt out of touch with what was going on. Very very negative

Josh Wood is probably the laziest professor Ive had to deal with in my three years of being here. He gives you a final paper, a final project and a final exam at the end of the semester to complete. Any questions you have must go through the ta first. Dr. Wood doesnt teach, he has multiple errors in his quizzes and tests and hes got a huge ego.

Honestly confused on why his ratings are slow. Took his class online yes reading is required welcome to History courses duh! Easy to understand if you do the material assigned and your part promise you easy A. Plus he is very understanding and explains things in a easy interesting historical way. Loved this professor never even met him.
Great experience. Super easy.

Had a family emergency and missed the first 2 exams of the first session course. Dr. Wood did not hesitate to help. The videos are a bit slow, but he provides the lecture slides and responds very quickly to emails.

Class is really easy if you actually put the effort in. I watched the videos and took notes. Exams were really easy. Not the most exciting material but straight-forward. I'm glad he uses notes instead of rambling on like some professors. Expect to work for your grade. Emails were quickly answered and friendly.

i took this class during the second session in the fall semester. Graded on 3 exams. The exams do relate to the books which are THEEE most borring thing you have ever read. He then selects info out of them which you would see as minor. His lectures are extreamly horible-like he is reading from a script and reading like a 5 year old. DONT TAKE HIM!

The class was poorly organized and he does not respond to emails asking for further explanations or assistance. Focuses on unimportant details in a GE course. Uploads prerecorded videos and still can't seem to find the time to assist students. The test questions are worded poorly and don't follow basic English.

Class content is slides with one bullet point so you have to take notes as quickly as possible while he talks. Three mutliple choice exams, but he uses trick questions. The textbooks are three novels. Very frustrating class because no notes provided. I would happily listen to the lectures if he gave notes. Its too much for a low level class.

Three or four hour-long lectures a week, and he talks really slowly. Three exams based on the content before each exam, not cumulative. Three novels as textbooks. Tricky and detailed exam questions, multiple choice and T/F. For a low level class, its very boring and time consuming. Took it for fun and it was not enjoyable.

Did not like him very much at all.  Participation mattered way too much. He did say from the very beginning that it was part of our grade, which, is why I did participate, but I got 0 points for it and he neglected to tell us that those points were more difficult to obtain than on the tests.  Avoid him and his classes at all costs. Trust me.

He's tough but you can tell he really cares about his students and goes the extra mile to explain things to you personally if you don't understand. He's kinda funny too. I hate history but I liked his class a lot because he challenged me and made me rethink things I thought I knew. Participation was mandatory, but he made that clear from the start.

Josh is a good professor. I learned a lot from him and his class wasn't too bad considering the subject matter. The only complaint I have is that I got an A in his class but it went down to a B after he gave me 25/100 for participation even though I showed up to every single class, got there on time, and did all my work on time.
Nice and funny! If you go to class and do your best to read and pay attention then your grade will be good. I had a lot of questions before the midterm and final and he took time to help me.
Really interesting class. He cares about the material and cares that you actually understand it. However, that also means it isn't a cakewalk. You'll get out as much as you put in.
He's hard but that's because he cares about the subject. There's a lot of reading, but its interesting and important. You'll work hard, but it'll be worth it. Class discussions are really good.
Wood is the worst teacher I've ever had the misfortune to interact with! He is Extremely unhelpful and not care of your grade at all!
HORRIBLE

He was a great teacher! He cared about Greek history and teaching it well, but he also understood that we all have lives outside of school. It was very easy to manage my time each week as long as I planned ahead. If you do the assignments and watch the videos each week, you'll be fine. Also, the exams were take-home open note so that was super nice

The best online lectures I have ever had! Prof Anderson explains everything very well and shows immense knowledge and interest in the things he is teaching, which makes it easier to learn. If you love learning about history or you are a history major, make sure to take Professor Anderson!

very great professor and gives fantastic lectures. gives a fantastic insight into today's world through the lens of the ancient Greek world. This class does use textbooks, but there is only one that you have to buy only $13. He does provide printouts for the other two books. if you like this class, I would recommend that you take HIST 3211.

Although this semester is not finished, I can strongly say that Dr. Anderson has been the best teacher I have had in my short time at OSU. The class subjects may be boring to some people but he makes plenty of dry humor jokes to keep your interest. Classical Greece was my favorite class of Spring 2023. 

For my harry potter fans, think Remus Lupin.

Extremely friendly and lenient grader, just be sure to attend lecture because it is required (but very interesting courtesy of professor anderson). Only assignments are a final paper 30%, attendance 10%, mid and final 60%, which are easy as long as you pay attention.

Good at teaching. Lectures are sometimes interesting but can be dull. And this is from someone who is interested in the topic, so I know its not me. Giving him a 2/5 because he posts nothing online and refuses to accommodate. Was out with strep for a week and he said no to any accommodations, so if you think youll need some, do not take him.

Professor Anderson is probably my favorite professor I have ever had. I took his class during summer semester 2020 and I genuinely enjoyed every moments of it. He's extremely engaging, passionate, and it's clear he cares about his students.

Greg is a phenomenal Professor. He lectures in a very engaging and he really cares about students. Go to office hours and chat with him before class, hes a great professor. Would highly recommend this as a history course.

Truly one of my favorite professors I ever had from any of the three colleges/universities I went to. He's very passionate about what he teaches and takes a real genuine interest in his students. I was fortunate enough to have him twice and will absolutely miss his lectures, including the virtual ones because of Coronavirus.
Take good notes or you'll fail. Besides that the class was very interesting and entertaining. You'll learn a lot.
Hilarious, kind, and genuinely takes interest in the students. Take good notes while he lectures and you will get an A

I would take the other reviews with a grain of salt. Although Prof Anderson is a nice man his class involved boring lectures everyday with no focus, 2 exams and one paper that creates the final grade. This is strictly a class for those who are already interested in and knowledgeable about Greek history otherwise it is not an easy A for a GE.

One of my favorite professors at Ohio State. Really is passionate about Greek history and you can tell by the way he lectures. I'm a history major and this was probably one of the easiest history courses I've taken here. If you are looking for an easy history GE, this is definitely your guy!
2 tests and a paper for the entire class. If you show up to class (which is mandatory), and take decent notes you can walk out with an A and a nice, british friend.

Dr. Anderson is a wonderful prof. Who gives great lectures. He seems very passionate about his field and teaches it in a historicist way, that is looking at history on its own terms. He's one of the best profs I've had in hist. And is also pretty easy. I would recommend him to anyone.
His lecture are great. History isn't my strong suit but I really enjoyed his class. Nicest guy ever.

We had 2 tests and 2 papers to write. No homework, just readings that were enjoyable most of the time. If you show up, you will pass. His lectures are really easy to follow, and interesting! His tests are the most straight forward tests I have had at OSU. He has a dry humor that is actually pretty funny. Definitely my favorite professor!
So nice! Really passionate about Greek history and likes to talk to his students before class. Funny. Exams are so easy.

I'm an engineer and had to take a History GE. He is the SWEETEST guy ever, and as long as you take really good notes and study for the exams you will do fine. Warning though - the lectures can be very, very boring. He does not have any slides so you need to actually pay attention all class in order to get good notes.

Not a big history person but this class was excellent. He is an engaging lecturer and is very passionate about the subject. I would recommend taking notes on a laptop because he covers a lot of material in a short amount of time with no powerpoint slides. I loved this guy and would recommend him to anyone.

He's an adorable british guy who loves to teach about the Greeks! He's fun to listen to, easy to talk to, and as long as you take basic notes there's no reason you shouldn't get an A. His tests are straightforward and simple, and he gives extra credit questions!

Professor Anderson was a fantastic lecturer.  From day one he had us won over with his quaint British accent and concise lectures. He is a very articulate and fun individual, and while he shows his knowledge well, he keeps everything down to earth.  My only knock on him was he made the class TOO easy to get an A in.  Otherwise, he was great.

Greg Anderson is an awesome guy. He is funny, very intelligent, extremely articulate, and very down to earth. He is very understanding and easy to get along with. I highly recommend him. You will enjoy his class.
This was by far one of my favorite classes. I wasn't looking forward to taking 398 but he made it absolutely wonderful!

A great professor who really seems to know his stuff. Makes history a story, and apart from a few boring lectures he keeps the class consistently interesting. Midterm and final were very, very easy and straightforward, so as long as you put in a bit of effort the class is just a great experience.

I don't know, maybe I'm the only one that didn't really like his teaching style.  If you're NOT a verbal learner, do NOT take this class.  He doesn't give you any powerpoint slides and you are constantly writing everything he says down.  If you miss something, you're pretty much screwed.  I stressed myself out getting an A in this class.

The most brilliant professor I have ever taken. His teaching style is smooth. Tells a story of Greece, uses pictures, poetry, textbook. He is enthusiastic about the subject and helping any and all students succeed. Take his class, it is worth it.
He is excellent.  He makes everything perfectly clear and easy to remember.  He has a pleasant demeanor and truly tries to connect with each student - even in a class of 70 students.  Take his class.
